38273836.review:
Back when i was a youngun, before all this CoD shite and whatnot, i distincly remember playing a game on my Gamecube caled Ty The Tasmanian Tiger. This particular game always stuck in my mind for being really fun to play, beautifully made and full of good ol' Australian humor.

(Too bad my disc was too scratched for me to play it back then ;w;)

But then around the start of 2017, my mate told me about the same game being ported to Steam. "Surely you jest?" i asked him. He wasn't pulling my leg. It was a thing. So for the first time in months, i deposited money into my Steam Wallet to buy a Steam game with which the price would be WAY higher due to conversion rates. But i didn't care, i wanted to play this shit and relive the memories i once had as a kid.

And boy, it all came flooding back, which each update to the port only getting more and more better. Normally, PC ports of games aren't as stellar as the console version, but Krome made sure that the PC port of their game would be spectacular, and it fucking is.

The levels, the rangs, the characters, the collectables, everything... It's bloody brilliant. And now with the ability to refight bosses, use the beloved Doomarang outside the final fight and with Steam achieves and trading cards, there's no way i couldn't not recommened this game.

Honestly, buy this and play this. If you're looking for a neat 3D-Platformer with a sort of Super Mario 64 collection aspect, bundled up with Aussie slang and humor, look no further. And consider the sequel to this, you won't be disappointed. And keep your eyes and ears open for the 3rd installment to soon be poarted onto the PC...

37963953.review:
I wouldn't say Ty's aged like wine or milk (to use the general gaming terms). It just...is. Thanks to the enhancements Krome have made with the port, it's exactly the same game I remember it being 15 years ago, playing it on the tiny TV in my dad's backroom in Perth. None of those moments where you go back to an old favourite and find muddy textures and clunky animations, it looks good.

There's a nice variety of level design, a decent quantity of mechanics, the collect-em-up aspects aren't too onerous. Swimming feels genuinely fun, a rarity for 3D games even today, especially good considering its age.

Some of the platforming can be a little bit floaty at times, and having to aim the boomerangs feels awkward, but these are mostly minor issues - the game controls well overall (played with a 360 controller). The music, while catchy, can sometimes be repetitive. 

Overall it's a good title. 3D collect-em-ups seem to have been having a bit of a minor renaissance in 2017, but Ty feels more enjoyable, more cohesive and less janky than, say, Yooka-Laylee. Would recommend.

37948552.review:
As a person who played this game way back when, I must say I love this game. When I saw it was getting a Steam port, I just had to get it. I've played it for quite a while now, and I must say there are a couple of things that do bug me. 

1. It's not exactly aged well. The animations are kinda cheesy, the game itself is quite a bit shorter than I remember it, and a few other minute things gameplay-wise. 

2. It's very tedious. This may be a personal thing, but it's got a lot of collectibles (and I mean a LOT). This is not a problem for most people, but as large as some of the worlds feel, it's quite annoying trying to collect them all. (even though I did).

So, in terms of my reccomendation, I'd certainly say that if you were an OG Ty player back in the day, then absolutely get this game. It's pretty much just as it was on the original console (I mean, obviously. It's a port). As for people who've not ever even seen the game before, I say you should still try it. It may not be a blast from the past for you, but it's certainly a good game even if you have never played it before.

37895487.review:
I've been playing quite a few HD remasters of games from my childhood, mainly on the PS3, and they were sometimes rather glitchy. Some games seemed to change for the worst with some decisions made. I remember hoping to see the Ty trilogy released as a HD collection, but I never did believe that anything like that would happen. Looks like I was wrong, and when I bought this game I was not disappointed at all. 

I wasn't disappointed because there were no obvious graphical glitches. It just looks like a smoother version of the original. Not only that, but some minor things were changed which made a big difference to players familiar with the game, and these changes are ones I applaud. For example, holding down triangle displays the boomerang menu. This was a feature originally introduced in Ty 2, and by adding this to this HD remaster it makes it easier to transition controls from the first game to the second, plus it makes selecting a boomerang easier. There are also little things like changes to sound effects, most notably the gliding sound effect (which again was introduced in the second game). The reason I appreciate these changes greatly is because as a kid I found the second game difficult to play after playing the first, so its good to see that the first game has been slightly changed to seem connected to its sequels.

Regarding the game itself, for people who are not interested in the original and are simply looking to play it for a new experience, this game has a lot to offer. The story is unique and quirky. Not only that, but everything is just a great big nod towards Australia. Exploring the Great Barrier reef and the Australian outback while meeting cockatoos and dingoes and cassowaries and hearing about stories of Bunyips and the Dreamtime. In a way it's educational, but it's also lovely to see a game which defines its location beautifully. Who doesn't want to learn a few Australian phrases?

The colours are beautiful and appealing. Not too bright and not too dull. The lighting effects in some areas are also pleasing, especially in the level "Bridge on the River TY". The voice acting sounds natural and the lines aren't cheesy, which is surprising since many child-friendly games include cheesy  quotes. The characters are all unique in their own way. Overall I think only one character has major development throughout the game, but honestly this isn't a game which needs overwhelming character development; we see the rest of the cast develop over the trilogy. In this game it's just fun to see the characters interact with Ty without needing to see them develop majorly.

Also, the soundtrack. I love the soundtrack. I used to have it on my iPod before it bust. Ty just has this soundtrack which you can hear and then say "Yup. This is from Ty". Not only that buts it's catchy, and certain leitmotifs are repeated from the main theme into certain levels, which I find most effective in the final battle. 

Lastly, I like to appeciate the animations, from Ty's idle animations to the four different movement animations depending on how hard you push the control stick. Even in games today some companies only do two animations for a character moving, maybe three if they're trying hard. And some games have dropped idle animations completely; either that or there's only one idle animation which barely does anything.

So overall, this is the sort of game I would force upon anyone who wants a new platforming experience. We live in an age now where anthropomorphic animals are growing rapidly in popularity, so this game would surely appeal to that audience. I love this game and I appreciate so many things about it. The only issue I have is the Infrarang not being as accurate as it was in the original, but honestly that doesn't hinder the game at all. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is looking at it right now; even if it's not your thing, it's worth a try!

37178511.review:
Review Date: 23-Nov-17

After all these years, I am very hapy to see Ty once again. I never was able to beat the game on my PS2 all those years ago... and now that I've seen the whole of it, I absolutely love the wackiness in the world. While I would nominate this game for the Suspension of Disbelief award for the Autumn Sale 2017 Awards, due to its sheer age and final porting to Steam, along with Ty 2, I have nominated it for the Labor of Love award.

Not too challenging of a game to beat, but if you want to 100%, you are in for a treat. Challenging pieces of loot to find in places of which you'd pay no mind. The story gives a chuckle, a giggle, a laugh; truest props to the level design staff. Don't take seriously the plot of this game, as a critical eye shows it is lame. To say it's terrible is just not right, as I shall now bring to light:

The story isn't meant to be taken seriously. It's just meant to be a fun collectathon featuring a tiger throwing boomerangs. Suspend your disbelief.

36535968.review:
As a child, I never fairly completed this game (shoutout to invincibility cheats and boomerang unlocks), let alone 100% completion, but 15 years later it landed in my Library and I set out to finish what I never tried as a kid.

This game is such a joy to play. Its goofy and fun and keeps you entertained for hours. The characters are quirky, the music is excellent, the levels are beautiful, and there's plenty to collect and explore for! I'm such a fan of collect-a-thon games, because they give me a motive to explore every corner of this virtual world and appreciate the design the developers had in mind. Level objectives are laid out for you, and sometimes even marked on the maps, but they still leave plenty of room for analyzing and creative thinking.

That being said, this game isn't difficult by any means. There are moments of frustration splattered in, but it's nothing to sweat over. The levels are fairly linear, if and only if you aren't looking to 100% complete the game. End world bosses aren't painfully difficult, but I also understand the intended audience for this game isn't looking for Dark Souls rage bosses. [spoiler](My exception being the second world boss, anything that involves sharks is too intense for me)[/spoiler]

Overall, this game makes my child-like heart happy. I'd love to see a release the second and third installments of this game remastered too. Thanks for the blast from the past, devs.

35461816.review:
This game man, it brings back so much nostalgia for me. I remember coming back from school one day and pops had a bought my brother and I an Xbox (fun fact I was scared shitless by the ambience in the main menu on the Xbox so I hurries as much as I could to start a game or have a game inside it when starting the console). The games we had were Halo CE and this game, I liked halo but this game was just so much more enjoyable for me, the simplicity but still the depth it brought forward was enough to satisfy my childish self to continue and play and grind to get all those golden cogs and eggs so I could test out all those different varieties of boomerangs and I simply had a blast.

Now when I look back I can still feel the joy I once felt purely from nostalgia, but with growing up and getting wiser and more perceptive, I also notice the games flaws. I felt it could get a bit too repetitive and some worlds were too large without really any way too get from point A to point B without running and feeling time consuming. 

Gameplay wise it feels satisfying to throw the boomerangs, you can feel the weight behind the biting attack and the enemies are mildly difficult depending on your experience of these kind of games. Bosses felt original and fun to fight against (for the most part) and most levels are fun and original (except the hog riding level, that shit is fucking trash). The movement is good mostly but the parts where you need to walk slowly eg. Over thin ice it can feel frustrating because it is inconsistent. But the core gameplay is good for the most part. And the positives outshines the negatives. 

The charming Australian caricature is funny and gives the game a sense of originality because if it didn't have the boomerang gameplay and the quirky accents it would pretty much be a rehash of every other plarform-type game that was consistently made during that time. And I think that's an strong plus.

Honestly the whole genre of platform games are old and don't really fit my taste in games anymore. I may try to pick them up to give my inner childishness some respect but I more easily get drawn to more modern games. But that doesent remove the enjoyment that I will have from these kind of games under smaller gaming sessions. So I will simply say that if you have played this game once when you were younger pick it up and play it for the nostalgic effect, and those that haven't played this game (furthermore even heard of this game) try to pick it up as I dare to say that it truly is a hidden gem of it's time when it washed released. I recommend it.

8/10
A great remaster of a PS2 era platforming / collect-a-thon game! BONZA!

Ty is the last of the Tasmanian Tigers as many years ago the Tasmanian Tigers battled the evil Boss Cass causing all of them to fall into the Dreamworld. Luckily, some kind of elder guy finds you and tells you that there still is a possibility to save your parents by collecting five talismans, as this will open the portal to this world.

Your friends quickly supply you with the knowledge and tools to go on your path in search of the talismans. This path includes dangerous roads filled with enemies of the evil Boss Cass. Luckily you brought your boomerang to hit those enemies right in their faces allowing you to collect the thundereggs required to power a Talisman teleporter machine.

Along the way you meet many of your friends which help you search the Australian Outback for all kinds of collectibles which will help you along the way.

+ Great platforming gameplay / Funny storytelling /  Great Australian music / Nostalgia / Ty's huge vocabulary (YOU BEAUTY!)
~ Too easy, definitely designed for kids (could also be a positive point if you have kids)

In short, a great platforming adventure in the Australian Outback!
Definitely recommended if you are a fan of the old Ratchet and Clank / Jak and Daxter games.

35145691.review:
This was a really fun collect-a-thon 3D Platformer that a lot of people remember from their childhood PS2 days, but since I had never owned the game when I was a kid, the game reminded me of other games I loved like Spyro and Croc. Either way, it gave me a nice little dose of nostalgia while also offering solid gameplay, controls, music, and beautiful graphics that are remastered from their original PS2 version and amped up with adjustable effects synonymous with PC-originated games like water reflection and anti-aliasing. The water in this game is gorgeous. The game is also very easy to run at 60 FPS with decent video settings.


The platforming in this game feels good and sometimes varies with needing certain mechanics like using different boomerangs to activate platforms or recognizing patterns and figuring out timing. It uses the game's resources very well and tends to keep a good balance with its mechanics. When you get a new tool, the next level makes good use of it like how most games do, but it also makes plenty of use of all your other tools too. It makes nothing feel wasted or added in just for filler. Some of the bosses are counterintuitive to figure out how to beat them, but most are fine. Boss fights are more like puzzles than combat, but a lot of games from the PS2 era had similar mechanics. Each level looks really nice and has a lot of small places to explore, making it really fun to run around the world and seek collectibles and secrets. There aren't any terribly difficult parts in this game, but there is still challenge in it as well.



It's a really fun game and I definitely would recommend it, especially to gamers who are fans of PS2 era games or people who like 3D platforming and games like Spyro, Croc, and Banjo-Kazooie. If you're a hardcore gamer looking for tough as nails platforming, this game isn't for you, but someone looking for a fun little gem will find value in this.

35097235.review:
Good God, do I love this game.

It's a part of my childhood. I probably spent the better part of one thousand hours wearing down my old PS2 disk years ago. I came back to it with the port here on Steam, and I can conclusively say that this is the best port I know to have been put on Steam, ever. The devs (the same studio from all the way back in 2002, though maybe not all the original staff) really put their hearts and souls into getting this classic to work on PCs. As near as I can tell, they even managed to convince the decade-and-a-half-old ORIGINAL GAME ENGINE to accept such modern amenities as adjustable graphics settings and, get this, re-bindable controls for keyboard. If that doesn't speak to the quality of both the game and the team behind it, then nothing does.

On to the game itself. The plot surrounds the eponymic character Ty, who is on a quest to save his family after they were imprisoned by the main antagonist, Boss Cass. The story makes somewhat little sense, but given the game's premise (anthropomorphic tiger collecting balls of light to save his family), I'll forgive it for that. Compare it to the likes of Banjo-Kazooie and you'll see that story generally came second or third to gameplay at the time this game came to be.

The game handles just like I remember from when I was young. It certainly isn't perfect; the camera can be mildly wonky and the jumping behavior is inconsistent at times, but Ty handles well and the biggest factor in the platforming is player skill, as it should be. One thing the game most certainly is NOT, is difficult. I 100%'d the game, at least as far as progress on the save is concerned (there's some extra stuff that doesn't count towards the total), in under 10 hours. But it was a blast the whole way through. I was brimming with so much nostalgia it gave me goosebumps at times.

If you liked the game when it was originally released, I can't recommend it more (at time of writing, it's even on sale!). If you're looking for a laid-back classic platformer, look no further. If you want to gallivant across a fictional Australia through worlds full of spirit filled with characters full of, well, character, then it doesn't get much better than this.

You don't get the single highest user satisfaction rating on Steam by making a bad game. Both the game itself and the quality of the port are absolutely outstanding, and the developers should be (and probably are) very proud of their work. Never before has the Internet laid eyes upon such a labor of love.

35008480.review:
Holy hell this game made me upset. Normally a game doesn't physically make me nauseous, but this one did. 

For starters, the game is very poorly optimized. I have a good PC that should be more that capable of running this piece of shit, but the framerate drops constantly, even on low settings.

But the thing that bothered me most was the sheer amount of annoying cutscenes, dialogue and tutorials. First of all, the game starts with a 15 minute pre-rendered cutscene that looks like garbage. Then during the game, these stupid, forgettable characters will never shut the fuck up even for a second. Literally the first level has like 15 tutorials in it. And they just pop up, you can't avoid them. Normally I'm not the kind of person to skip tutorials or cutscenes but good god, it really got out of hand and I started having to skip everything so I wouldn't puke. Of course, not doing the tutorials means I had no idea what most of the things in the game were for so it just seemed like I was picking up useless objects.

But probably the worst part about this is that they can't just say something like "This here is a checkpoint. If you die, you restart from here." No. They have to have this fucking senile cockatoo go "OY MATE ONE TIME I WAS DOWN AT THE BARBY AND THIS BLOKE CAME UP TO ME AND STARTED BLOWIN' ME MATE, BUT CRIKEY I WAS DAFT AS A WALLABY AND DIDN'T REALIZE THIS BLOKE HAD DRUGGED MY MARTINI AND WHAT DO YOU KNOW I WOKE UP IN THIS DODGEY SHACK, MATE!" Yes, I get it, the shack is a checkpoint now shut the fuck up. They have the most long-winded lore-friendly ways to explain every tiny fucking game mechanic that's commonplace in every platformer. No, I really don't need to have a lore reason to collect five bonus blue koalas in every level. I really don't. And I sure as hell don't need you to explain it to me.

You might say that I didn't spend enough time with this game, and that the amount of tutorials and annoying bullshit cutscenes go down as the game progresses, but it doesn't matter how good a game gets if the beginning of the game makes you want to blow your brains out. You wouldn't stab an active soldering iron into your eyeball just to get an ice cream cone afterwards.

I wasn't going to mention this at first, but now I'm on rant so I may as well: The visuals look like they were drawn by a fucking 12 year old on DeviantArt. I'm sorry, but you know it's true. If you told me that Ty was designed by a third grader, I would honestly believe you.

My last gripe is that the bite move makes a sound effect that makes it sound like Ty is literally biting into his lip. It's the grossest sound and it makes me want to puke.

The only positive things I can say about this game are that picking up the gems is satisfying and the music is alright. I thought about it for a while, but those are literally the only compliments I can give to this piece of trash.


This game is literally shovelware, and it's really no different from any of the other failed platformer mascots like Bubsy. I could probably find this game in the $1 bargain bin at WalMart. The amount of people calling this game a classic makes me lose so much faith in the gaming community. Everyone is either nostalgia blind as fuck, or have no clue about game design, or even what fun is. This is the reason so many shitty games have such high ratings. The only way a game will have a low rating on Steam is if it has a technical issue that prevents the game from running, or some popular YouTuber says it's bad so all these kids give it a bad review to try to fit in. 

Fuck this game.

EDIT: I don't get why this game coming out 15 years ago is an excuse for it to be terrible. Plenty of actual good games came out before and during that time that still hold up today. Am I supposed to give this game a good review just because "the port is good" (which it isn't, by the way)? If someone did an HD port of Superman 64 to Steam, and it was an amazing port would you give it a good review? No. Because Superman 64 is terrible.

34714462.review:
I remember as a kid how much I loved playing this game. TY was a huge part of my childhood and I remember stumbling across this game in one of my local game stores. I must have been around 9 years old when I first played it back in the day and I have so many fond childhood memories of this classic childhood gem. When I found out sometime last year that the developers of the series wanted to remaster and revamp the game up to today`s modern day and age technology, I couldn`t have been more thrilled and excited to see one of my favourite childhood games comeback to life. I only just got a brand new PC a few weeks ago and I couldn`t wait to buy it on Steam and sit down with this gem to take a nice stroll down memory lane. 

The game feels like exactly how I remember it. The developers have done a smashing job on making this an amazing port of a classic. The visuals in the game look beautiful, the soundtracks to the levels are still the good old same fun rocking tunes that I love and remember. There`s been quite a few improvments though that I have noticed which make this port even more of a perfect hit such as the loading times which have been dramatically improved over the original game. Taken no more than 2 - 3 seconds max to load up a single level or your saved game file which is fantastic. I love how they have enhanced and revamped everything in the game and the developers have certainly put alot of hard work and effort into making this a solid good tremendous port that is well worth the valueble purchase of your wallet. 

TY is a beautiful gorgeous 3D platformer that is well worth investing your money in if your a huge fan of many other great platformers out there that were great back in the day from the likes of Ratchet and Clank , Jak and Daxter , Sly Cooper then you will most certanily love this. If you`ve already played the original back in the day in your childhood then by all means this is without a doubt worth another round of replaying through. If your a newcomer to the series but are a fan of platfomers then TY is a game definitely worth giving a shot and I highly recommend it to all those platformer fans out there who have yet to discover the series as well as newcomers out there who are willing to give it a try.

For those who are new to the games TY is more of a open ended 3D platformer game that is very easy to pick up and enjoy though the game is quite linear as well. The storyline of the game is pretty much simple, you guide TY through a number of levels collecting a variety of different collectables on your travels such as opals , thunder eggs and bilbies that help you progress through the game. The main plot of the game for background purposes is to retrieve back all the talismans from the evil boss Cass who plans to use them for his own uses to rule the world. 

Features in the game as a small breakdown 
- Open ended charming 3D platformer with a fun cast of characters to meet
- A huge variety of boomerangs that help aid you in your quest 
- Run . jump , swing and glide through 17 amazing levels full of great platforming and challenge 
- Offers a nice variety of mini games
- Beautiful and updated enhanced graphics

The performance of the game is very good. It runs pretty much smooth with very little hiccups. The design of the levels are stunning and have been reworked , revamped and polished very well to golden standards. It`s amazing to see that even 15 years on after it`s release that TY still has the power of showing how good and strong the 3D platformer genre is. This is a worthy port and a prime example of a how a great port of a classic should be done. It`s been handled with great love and care by the developers and I couldn`t be more greatful and thankful to them for making this happen. It`s such a warm feeling inside and feels good to have this classic childhood franchise back in my life again. Everytihng in the original is on par with what they have done with the port. 

What I will also say is as well is that TY is one of those platformers out there that is more forgiving than other hardcore platformers such as Crash Bandicoot. You will find that many parts of the game can be forgiving at times making this ease of accessible to newcomers out there who may not be familiar with the core of the game`s mechanics. Just as an example  to show how forgiving the mechanics are to those who are new and unaware the checkpoint system within the levels of the game are quite frequent and there`s quite alot them placed through out the levels which is nice since it can benefit those who may struggle in later parts of the game whereas compared to the hardcore platformer types out there such as Crash Bandicoot, you`ll find checkpoints are place very far out in between. Also the gamepad controls for the game are very easy to pick up and learn and there is no need to hassle around with controller configuration as the game has full integration support of controller gamepad`s which means all the controls are all automatically set up for you and ready to use when you boot the game up. 

My conclusion summary and my final thoughts on the game

A beautiful and very well crafted port that I couldn`t recommend more. If your a fan of the old school 3D type platformers then TY is a another one of those childhood revival classics that you will love and if you have yet to dip your feet into this series then by all means give it a try if you have some cash floating around because it is a blast to play and I would recommend this to any newcomer who is just looking for a relaxing, casual and fun game to pick up. On a final note I want to say a massive thank you to Krome Studio`s for brinigng back one of my all time favourite nostalgia classics of all time. So many great childhood memories with this game and it feels so great to take a nice trip down memory lane to relive this classic. Absolutely stunning and amazing game that deserves another chance at getting rebooted in the near future. A great game with great value at a great affordable price.

BONZA! You still got the magic KROME Studio`s

Score - 9/10

( PROS )
- A solid well hand crafted 3D platformer with smooth and responding controls
- Great cast of characters each with there own unique fun personalities
- Epic and awsome soundtracks for each and every level
- Great variety in weapon choice of the number of boomerangs on offer which each define many different types of damage and wondeful effects that lead to great and fun gameplay when using them
- Good camera controls and cut-scenes render very good

( Negitives ) 
- A few minor bugs and little frame rates clipping from time to time but overall runs very smooth in most parts of the game.

That concludes my review and my very first review for a Steam product.

33613831.review:
TY the Tasmanian Tiger is one of those games that starts slow and grows on you. I never played it back in its original heyday with the other mascot games, but it does compare favorably to games such as Spyro the Dragon, Sly Cooper, and Jak and Daxter. There are nine environments, with one hub world and one boss world, with plenty of stuff to do that allows for exploration and decent combat and puzzle solving.

 The only 2 problems I had that were of any substance were 
1) TY literally only saying 1 liner catch phrases, with an occasional dumb question to progress the dialogue (seriously, every other character had some personality, while TY would be better off as Gordon Freeman), and 
2) seemingly random patches in the environment that you aren't supposed to enter, but can anyways. Going up on that snowy mountain? Hope you don't hit a patch of rock that isn't covered in snow, because you're about to go for a slip n slide ride!

Otherwise, there was some minor stuff that is just pedantic, so I won't go over them. There is plenty of stuff to collect. You don't get punished a multitude of times for the same mistake (e.g. if you jump into a flamethrower, you take damage once and then either get knocked back to your starting position or keep going, with a short immunity, instead of getting knocked off a cliff and having to run all the way back). Most NPCs are interesting, the game doesn't unnecessarily drag on, and the boomerangs and their many varieties are integrated well enough that it is worth using most of the upgrades for a variety of situations.

Overall, it's a solid mascot/3D action platformer from the PS2 era, a rarity on the steam platform. It doesn't have much to set it apart from other mascot games, other than an Australian theme, but there are very few if any major drawbacks. If you like Spyro, Sly Cooper, Crash, Jak and Daxter, etc etc this is a solid nostalgia trip but won't be anything terribly new. If you haven't, it's a solid entry that showcases what these types of games are about. I would give it a 7/10, great for on sale to try, or even good outside of a sale to scratch that mascot game itch.

33335967.review:
Considering its age, this game has held up pretty well, and there's basically one reason as to why. Unlike a lot of contemporaries it doesn't shove garbage awful minigames down your throat constantly. Yeah, there are a few but they're usually both brief and really easy and the vast majority of the gameplay (95%+) is platforming and collecting.

The game does feel a little archaic at times - the camera isn't great, the glide/jump mechanic is a bit weird and inconsistent, and the boss battles are all kind of rubbish. But Ty controls decently and the game gives you all the tools you need to complete the game & find everything should you be willing to put in the effort.

The game also runs out of ideas for the last third of the game, with the three levels in the third tier of levels all reusing scenery and ideas from the first six levels. There's kind of a fresh spin on it to some degree, but it still feels kind of like filler, especially that second water level which is just... pointlessly spacious. As well there are some really annoyingly hidden things in the first water level that I wasn't a fan of (probably spent more time there than any other level). I think the length of the game is just right for this kind of game though, I got 15 hours out of it and felt pretty satisfied with that, not really craving much more but not feeling like I didn't get enough either.

It is a bit dated of a game but, honestly? I found this more enjoyable than Yooka-Laylee on the whole, even with its problems. It's just a nice, refreshing dose of 3D platforming & collecting the way I like it, without the pointless fluff that drags down a lot of contemporaries (Spyro 2 & 3 and the first Sly Cooper game both come to mind). And for $15 it's a pretty solid deal (though I got it for cheaper). Definitely pick it up if you're interested - I have zero nostalgia for this game as I'd never played it before but I can decisively recommend it.

33254781.review:
This game just wants you to play it.

Pros:
+ The nostalgia is great
+ Australian quirks/accents, however inaccurate and stereotypical, are great.
+ The remastered graphics are spot on, little old in some spots, but still stylized enough to not make you care.
+ The controls... it's like this game actually wants you to play it, unlike other platformers.


Con:
- Too easy?
- Too short, but still, 100% this probably averages 9-15 hours of solid time.
- Semi-lack of story, it's short, it quick, it's to the point, but isn't that what makes the old platformers great?

The controls: First off, it's so refreshing to have a platform game that actually wants you to succeed and play it. Unlike others that have hefty, slow, unresponsive controls, Ty does it right. The aiming, the movement, the jumping, every about this game makes it less about lining up or revving up movement, and more about just doing it. Compared to other platformers, the frustration level of missing a jump, or stutter-stepping around is just absent.

If you loved Ty the first time, or want a brisk refreshing Australian style platformer, I can't reccomend this enough. Heck, just for the fabulous controls it's almost worth $5 in itself. If I could I'd prefer almost every platformer had controls like Ty, at least for the basics.

33100302.review:
An excellent port of an excellent game.

TRUST ME YOU ARE GONNA WANT A GAMEPAD FOR THIS ONE!

I never got to play this when it came out, but a friend of mine had it.  I saw it on steam and figured I'd give it a shot.

Boy I'm glad I did.  This game was one of the many "early 2000's" platformers / collectathons that were oh so popular back then.  Some others of note being the Jak and Daxter series, ratchet and clank, hell, even spongebob battle for bikini bottom.  A bunch more too.

Anyways, the movement is a little bit faster than you'd expect at first, but you get used to it.

Nine levels to explore with a bunch of different boomerangs to collect.  You could probably blaze through the game pretty fast if you wanted to, but it's well worth grabbing as much as you can along the way.  The maps are fairly large later on.

The game is very forgiving with some mechanics that other games are much more blunt with.  For example, you can swim underwater for a LONG time before drowning, which is really nice.  Checkpoints are frequent and deaths do not interrupt boss battles.  The boomerangs are essentially infinite ammo ranged weapons with some strings attached depending on the set you are using.

The game has a very nice flow with the animations used.  SMOOTH AS BUTTER!  The game runs pretty well on low to midrange systems, so you shouldn't have to worry about lowering settings.

Story wise, it's a little all over the place, but that's OK given it's a platformer with multiple different levels with very different settings.  The cutscenes have a sort of TV-show quality that seemed "OK" but didn't really detract from the overall experience.

to summarize:

+ 2000's era platformer, find the things to get to the next place to find the things, etc.
+ BOOMERANGS!  Fun as hell to use.
+ Diverse levels with mixed platforming and combat.
+ No major glitches of note.
+ Interesting boss fights
+ Looks fantastic, some subtle graphical updates really make this 15-year-old game shine.
+ Voice acting is great.  Get used to australian accents and words that leave the uninitiated confused.

~ Music is good, but gets repeditive.
~ Camera can get a little wonky in some areas, but is overall fine.

- 100% can be a grind if you miss certain collectibles on your first run through. There is a cheat code that reveals collectibles that you can use if you really need to.


If you are looking for that authentic early 2000's platforming experience, I highly recommend this game.

32942375.review:
As my first review of a game, I wanted to ensure it was a game that was especially dear to me. It would need to be a game that has secured a special place in my heart, and resonate with me on multiple sentimental levels.
 
Ty the Tasmanian Tiger can lay claim to this feat.

[b] TLDR at bottom [/b]

Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was released in 2002 for the PS2, Xbox, and Gamecube. My copy of the game was for the PS2 system. Being released alongside contemporaries Ratchet, Sly Cooper, and Jak, I saw Ty as part of this hypothetical Sony mascot tetrarchy of heroism. Wicked Australian accent? Boomerang slinger? Cool character design and art style? Ty was totally awesome. Being around 6 or 7 years old at the time, it was a flourishing era of elementary imagination and exploration. I would daydream about my video game heroes teaming up, indulge in make-believe adventures with them during recess, and make poorly-scribbled doodles on my spelling tests. It was great.

[i] 15 years later, the game is still great. [/i]

There is a decent number of "nostalgia" reviews. Which is just fine, but I wanted to give a little more information on the game and why one should check it out, especially if you are younger, and have not grown up with this game or its sequals.

[u] Brief Overview [/u]
For those that are more unfamiliar with this game, or have heard of it and simply not played it before, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger game is an action/adventure collect-em-up game similar to other titles such as Jak and Daxter, Banjo-Kazooie, and Super Mario 64.
Ty is a young Thylacine who discovers that an evil cassoweary (weird bird/ostrich thing) named Boss Cass has stolen a handful of mystic talismans and banished your parents to the Dreaming. The talismans are now scattered across the Outback and it is up to Ty to track them down, defeat Cass, and rescue his family!

[u] Straight-to-the-point Review [/u]
[b] Graphics: [/b] The game is beautiful. The colors are bright and vivid, the remastered textures look excellent, the water looks refreshing, and the dynamic shadows are just the icing on the cake. Avid players of the original will also notice additional decorations and foliage in the levels as well. The FPS is superb. Never dropped below 60. It's pretty crazy remembering that the game came out 15 years ago.

[b] Gameplay: [/b] The platforming in the game is very fun and diverse in nature that differs between the various levels in the game, with different tasks in these levels that provide some variety in the odd jobs you need to complete for the game's primary collectable, Thunder Eggs. There are also secondary, optional collectibles: Golden Cogs. These are acquired in order to create "techno rangs," which are separate from the boomerangs you obtain through story progression. Controls are tight and extremely refined for keyboard and mouse, making the platforming more enjoyable, and the combat fluid.

[b] Weapons: [/b] Guns, swords, spells, miracles, ninjutsu, runes... those are pretty neat and all.
However, there is a certain satisfaction that can only be achieved through hitting something in the face with a boomerang that explodes.

[b] Levels: [/b] Ty the Tasmanian Tiger features the popular World Hub mechanic. This certainly isn't a bad thing when it works well, which it does. There are 10 primary levels, 9 of which are the levels you explore to retrieve Thunder Eggs. Each level is unique. Though some do indeed share similarities, they are very distinct from one another in design, and are all quite memorable and fun to explore.

[b] Characters: [/b] They are all enjoyable and goofy. Some a bit more odd than others. Some may give you trust issues. They may not be super fleshed-out with deep backstory, but they have their charms, and that's enough for me.

[b] Cutscenes/Animation: [/b] This is the primary area in which this game shows its age. The animations for some of the enemies and NPCs look very dated, especially during the in-engine cutscenes within the levels. However, this is forgivable understanding that the game was released in 2002, and that it doesn't subtract from the gameplay itself.
On the flip side, the intro cutscene and primary story cutscenes are rendered and animated at a much higher quality, and look pretty dang awesome. They invoke a sense of "Indie animated movie" style.

[b] Music: [/b] Ah yes. This is one of those games. One of those few games that you play the full soundtrack on YouTube while playing other games. The music is one of the most memorable, nostalgia-trip-inducing aspects of this game. The reason that there is a soundtrack available for purchase with this game. It's style is simple, satisfying, and has a very distictive Australian twang to it. Many of the tracks delve into quite a wide range of genre styles, but come full circle and include catchy motifs in the tunes.
Understand that the soundtrack isn't the next revolutionary soundscape, and some of the enjoyment may be nostalgia-fuelled, but it is certainly catchy, addicting, and definitely worth a listen.

[u] Conclusion/TLDR [/u]
Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is as solid a adventure/platformer title now as it was 15 years ago. The remastered graphics and textures are awesome. 60 FPS. Tight controls even with keyboard and mouse. The in-engine animated sequences look quite dated, but are forgivable. Story cutscene animations are excellent. The characters are charming and goofy. The music is very catchy and addicting.

[u] Overall Rating [/u]
[h1] Totally Wicked! [/h1]

(For those curious, I did indeed derive part of my name from this game. You'll [i] never [/i] guess where the other half came from.)

Would recommend this game to anyone. It is a must-buy for fans of the original that grew up with it, as well as those seeking a classic platforming, collect-em-up Outback adventure.

Very much looking forward to the future remasters of the sequels!

32747847.review:
[h1]An necessary throwback to both the 3d Platformer and Collectathon genres, as well as the PS2 era[/h1]

[u]~ Graphics - 4/5 ~[/u] [list]
A fairly generic (of its time) cel-shaded, though refreshing if you've not played any game visually resemblant this recently.
In spite thereof, Krome Studios has ameliorated this (once antiquated) look, via a myriad of such postprocessing options as antialiasing; x8 MSAA and Screeen Space Ambient Occlusion - leaving the game appearing majorly updated: less jaggéd and more shadowed. 
However, the models are still relatively low-poly in addition to the still very basic textures - lessening the general graphical quality.
(For a mod which further improves Ty's graphics, look no further than [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/411960/discussions/0/361798516962057966/] (Ty graphical mod} [/url] )

[u]~ Gameplay - 3/5 ~[/u] 
This game is one of very few decent 3d platformers on Steam, with some of the least janky platforming controls, apart from [spoiler]the gliding toward the end of the Lenny The Lyrebird stage[/spoiler]. 
As well thereas, this game is one of the first and only of very few to successfully employ particle effects as a means of rewarding the player - granting a much more fulfilling experience. 
The controls are untweakable, which hinders accustomation with the clunky control scheme, and navigating on foot with Ty - in terms of game feel - is heavy and slow. 
Krome Studios missed out on many opportunities of mechanically deepening their game:- [spoiler]too many of the boomerangs serve no purpose; there are no boomerang-specific enemies; the game concludes too quickly; and overly repurposed assets dominate the game.[/spoiler]

[u] ~ Story - 2/4 ~[/u]
The narrative - an archetypal [i]finding one's family[/i] "adventure" - is severely lackluster and seems rather rushed, with much left unexplained. Characters tend to be rarely humorous and mostly annoying; and their incessantly bombarding use of Australian slang feels forced. 

[u]~ Optimisation - 2/5 ~[/u]
Indeed - the graphical settings are tweakable to suit your PC build, yet the advancement to Direct X11 highlights the poor ageing of the game's optimisation - the game obviously lacks textural RGB channel-packing and seems to lack any LODs. Adding thereto, TY appears illogically locked at 60 frames per second.

[b]~ Verdict - 5.5/10 ~[/b]
Though an appreciated contribution to the 3d Platformer Renaissance, Ty emphasises the need for more effort to be put into 3d Platformers-- if their 2016 and -17 rebirth are to fulfill the heretofore unactualised predictions of market domination.

[h1]Foreword[/h1]

I have to commend Krome Studios on this one, [i]this[/i] is how you handle a remaster even if it's not tagged as it.
They respected the original game and then improved on it making this the best version of the game available

Unlike Sony, which was more than glad to outsource the remastering process of their titles of the same period and didn't care if the games came out worse as a result.


[h1]Review[/h1]

Ty is a character action platformer, from the days where platformers were a dime a dozen, it was and still is a good one at that but thing that makes it stand out from the rest is the very strong Aussie flavour.

The textures, world and character models show the game's age but Krome did an excellent job bringing it to current day.
The one suggestion I can give would be to turn off the bloom, newcomers might prefer having it on but for those that are reliving memories or want an experience closer to the original (and I don't mean this in a bad way) having it off is the way to go.

31782332.review:
When Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was released, back in 2002, I was 12 years old. I missed out on it because I didn't own any "nextgen" video game consoles back then. That's a shame, 12-year-old me would have loved it way more than I like it now, and I do. This is a game that's good and worthwhile, but features some problems common to 3D platformers from back in its time which make it not as good as it had all the right to be.

The game follows the story of Ty, a Tasmanian tiger (well, duh) who is supposedly the last descendant from a proud tribe that fought off evil avian fiend Boss Cass, foiling his ultimate plan of obtaining the five talismans of unfathomable power in his attempt dethrone mammals from the top of the food chain to honor his dinosaur ancestry. The game itself kicks off with Ty casually playing hide and seek with his adoptive family of bilbies when, suddenly, he falls into a hole and meets the spirit of an odd sage of sorts. The spirit tells Ty about his ancestors' deeds, and that Boss Cass is trying to gather the talismans again, and that Ty is the only one who can stop Cass's evil plans. There's something rather charming and nostalgic about the pre-rendered cutscenes used in this game instead of in-engine cutscenes that are more common nowadays. I really enjoy those, if only for the retro feel alone. As a main character, Ty strikes me as an awesome, enthusiastic, energetic and brave marsupial that is always ready to run around, hop on difficult platforms and land his boomerang on every baddie's face.

To aid Ty in his quest, he counts with a roster of endearing NPC friends, all based on Australian animals, each with their own charmingly exaggerated cartoon-esque personality. In fully voice acted (take note, Yooka-Laylee) cutscenes, they tell Ty about small missions he has to accomplish in order to gather special tokens, as well as hints about the controls and the game's mechanics, and warnings about the evil fiends and hazards that Ty may need to face ahead of him. Every character has an awesome Australian accent which adds even more charm to this radical outback adventure, and every cutscene and dialog in the game is rich in silly yet endearing humor. Among the roster of characters, there's the aforementioned titular character, plus an old cockatoo named Maurie who sounds like a wise yet slightly crazy old man, a koala scientist named Julius who acts in a stereotypical nerdy way that's rather endearing, and an awesome handful of others. I particularly like the mysterious Sly, and it saddens me that the game's story didn't explore this character in more detail at all.

Speaking of outback, the overall graphical design in this game is spot on, in spite of the low tech nature of it. Sure, they may look way too polygonal, pointy and unappealing for today's standards, but they're nothing if not effective in capturing that neat Australian feel, in both the scenery and the characters. Rainbow Cliffs looks and feels like a spot on Australian scenery, and every level represents, in one way or another, some kind of landscape that one may encounter in Australia, except with awesome platforming and treacherous traps thrown in for good measure. In his journey, Ty will go through rainforests, the outback desert itself, snowy mountains, beaches, and many other kinds of natural landscapes that occur in Australia, and that makes for an epic thematic experience I really enjoy. 

As far as sound goes, I like the voice acting and the sound effects, they're appropriately comical and cartoonish, and fit well with the atmosphere of the game. The dialogs are particularly funny, always featuring some comedic exchanges and overall endearingly cheesy personalities. The music is nice as well, going for a mix between relaxing guitar music and some Australian tribal instruments (like the didgeridoo), always sounding appropriately upbeat when needed, and more calm and contained when the situation calls for it. It's always catchy, though, and that's a plus in my book. As I write this, I have the Rainbow Cliffs song stuck in my head.

Speaking of Rainbow Cliffs, I find the way this game deals with level design rather interesting. Rainbow Cliffs serves as an "open world" area of sorts, full of tiny secrets to be uncovered and serving as a hub area to enter the levels as well as a safe, open space for you to test out your movement skills. The levels themselves are an interesting beast: while some 3D platformers from the past went for straight-up linear levels with maybe a few secret passages (like the original Crash Bandicoot or the PS1 Pac-Man game) and others went for the open-level fetch quest style (like, say, Super Mario 64 or Banjo-Kazooie), this game goes for a mix between the two approaches. Every level has a linear-ish path that the player may follow from beginning to end, but along the path there are some more open-ish places that players may want to explore in order to find special tokens, discover shortcuts and special areas, accomplish certain missions assigned to them by the NPCs or rescue some bilbie friends. This semi-linear approach is effective because you hardly ever feel lost (and even if you do, every level counts with a map that you can look at by pressing the menu button) but it still gives you something more to do than simply going straight from start to finish. The movement mechanics themselves work fine, and the individual sections of the levels are well designed to the point where it's fun to run, jump, battle, swim, glide and do whatever else you need to do to get them Thunder Egg thingies.

This semi-linear design, however, comes with a price that I can't overlook: it sometimes tries to force the player to follow the predetermined path in the cheapest ways possible, like invisible walls and twisty, redundant paths. It feels realy cheap to not be able to jump to something that's right in front of you because of a stupid invisible wall that's disguised as a handful of foresty-looking sprites. This kind of thing was way too common in platformers back in the day, limiting the player's exploration possibilities, and it throws me off a bit.

Now, one thing I really like about this game's overall mechanics is the "key-and-keyhole" aesthetic of acquiring new skills and applying them to open new paths. Whether it's gliding with two boomerangs, swimming, or any other skill that Ty may get to learn during the game, learning new skills in a level always opens up new possibilities, both in previous levels where something may have been out of reach (or just hard to reach) in your first visit, and in Rainbow Cliffs, where you're finally able to access a rainbow scale that you couldn't get to before, or a new set of levels to play in order to obtain some Thunder Eggs. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you obtain a new power that allows you to get to a place that you previously located but couldn't reach is one of the things I like the most in games, as it gives the experience a sense of progression that no other form of media has. I do feel like this aspect of the design should have been explored more than it was, maybe adding some extra secret stuff that you can only open with the right 'rang, but that could have alienated portions of the target audience that prefer their games to be straight-forward, it's okay that they chose not to do that.

Now, I know I complimented the level design a lot, and while it's definitely good, it is far from perfect. One huge problem I have are the bosses which, while mostly fun, may sometimes be pretty close to impossible to figure out on your own if you're dumb like me. I had to look up walkthroughs for three of the bosses, including the final battle one, and I can't help but assume this is a flaw of the game itself. I mean, I never had problems figuring out bosses in any other 3D platformer, so maybe this one didn't care to make the bosses intuitive to figure out.

31211166.review:
[h1]TY也好，雷曼也罢，只要让我回到那时候的感觉都是好的经典游戏。[/h1]

这款游戏不知道为什么，从几个月前就在我steam商店界面下拉出更多内容的第一个，当时看官方视频和截图觉得挺好的，就把它放进了愿望单里，进来看到打折我就买下来了。
[b]以上是我怎么邂逅这只老虎的过程。现在，我们来看看这只老虎的年龄[/b]

泰思虎奇幻冒险（TY the Tasmanian Tiger 以下简称为泰斯虎 游戏主角就称TY）是款比较老的游戏IP，不过国内很多玩家都没有听说过，算是个小众IP，我也是经历过上面的事件才知道有这IP的。我们现在所评测的这款是TY第一个系列的steam版，是不是重置的我暂时不知道，就把它当做steam版了。
据泰斯虎4官方画集考据，泰斯虎1大概是在2001年发售的：画集下翻不久会翻到显示整个系列的TY形象和对应发布时间的一页，而泰斯虎1里TY的形象下面写着2001，可以大致确定1代正式发售时间为2001。另外在前面还有2000年TY形象，在泰斯虎4里他被叫做"Concept Ty"，说明这形象是官方原稿，最初始的TY形象。
除了泰斯虎1代在steam上，还有另外两个系列也在steam上：[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/287840/]4代[/url]以及现在正处于EA的[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/411970/]2代[/url]

[b]的确是只很老的老虎呢，不过不能光看这老虎的年龄，还要看它本体是怎么样的。先从外观看起[/b]

因为是个老游戏，所以画质并不是那么好，听别人说是ps2时期的，当然也有可能是我为了提高帧数开了低特效。虽说如此，细节上倒是做的挺到位的，比如说TY的回旋标，当他正在拿剧情必得的属性回旋标，他的身上会被回旋标特效的光 照映，有变色的感觉；此外，地图上某些风景远看也是极好的，值得截图留念。不要小看任何老游戏的地图细节。

[b]然后就是它的内在，也就是肉质，因为我们一会要吃掉这只老虎[/b]
不能做个画面党，不然你会错失很多经典游戏的，因为很多老游戏为了弥补画质的缺陷，把游戏内容做的丰富了。比如说这个游戏，它虽然画质不是很好，但它有很多很多的收集要素啊！
这个游戏里的关卡虽然不是很多，但都内容丰富，并且地图足够你跑上一会。虽说如此，官方说的17个关卡里只有9个有丰富的收集要素，其余的都是boss战，但也足够了。
简单的列出所有收集要素（按重要程度分）：
1.这个游戏里最主要的收集要素叫thundereggs，通过完成关卡内的任务获得，用于解锁当前关卡系列的boss关，当然打完boss后你就可以获得对应的属性回旋标，用于打开新的关卡系列的通道，此外还有次于thundereggs的收集要素：齿轮（Cogs），用于解锁功能特殊的回旋镖。另外，收集它们的数量会直接影响到存档收集百分比
2.游戏里最基础的收集要素为欧泊，每个关卡一共有300个，第一次收集的欧泊不会因为退出关卡而消失，直到你用300个兑换了thundereggs；笼子里的动物也是基础的收集要素，5个全部收集到自动兑换；当你至少完成一个任务后，在关卡开头那里会有限时挑战，游戏界的限时挑战都一样不必多说
3.有个不必要但是成就需要的是Picture Frames（图片），图片藏在几乎隐形的箱子里，某个回旋标可以察觉到；以及在选关卡地图专有的贝壳，集齐有惊喜
全部收集齐需要花上大量时间（不看攻略大概20小时，或者根本不知道有隐藏箱子？）
boss战一开始容易让人蒙蔽，不知道怎么打，但当你知道boss套路后，你会轻松的打过这个boss的，boss战就是学习并发掘打这个boss的方法。老实说，在下的各位boss，都是垃圾，再加上TY是特别强悍的主角，于是……
为什么不来说生命值方面呢，因为这游戏太简单以至于真正GG都要刷起来。

[b]肉质不错啊，这么紧密，看来能很好的吃上一顿了。不过呢，我想要再看看这只老虎的声带[/b]
背景音乐比较的轻快活泼，而且头尾衔接的好，容易洗脑循环，如果想要听的话，还请去购买泰斯虎4DLC Soundtrack，我还以为只有4代的音乐，没想到它把所有系列的音乐都收录进来了hhh。此外，这个游戏的人物都有自己的配音，而且非常有特色，让人回味，不过配音这点让我觉得这是重置版，因为我认为真正的老游戏鲜少有配音。音效也不错，回旋标撞到墙壁的声音很清脆。

终于把这只老虎介绍完了，现在开吃！

总结：
+丰富的收集要素
+音乐优秀，值得去购买Soundtrack
+有配音
+游戏总体来说比较简单

+-IP小众
+-游戏画面不是太好，不过因为这样内容才能那样丰富

-为什么Soundtrack资料等都在泰斯虎4DLC那里！

总之，虽然这个游戏甚至整个IP冷了点，但总体质量还是不错的，优秀经典的老3d游戏，值得非画面党一玩。如果你对此有兴趣可以把整个系列添加至愿望单，并在打折期间一并购入，希望这个系列不会带给你失望。

30966039.review:
[h1]TY the Tasmanian Tiger[/h1]
Ty ist ein unglaublich guter 3D Platformer, welcher man allen Fans des Genres und Nostalgiker ans Herz legen sollte. Diese Neuauflage des tasmanischen Tigers ist trotz des Alters, eines der besten Jump and Run Spiele seit langem. Ich hatte einen riesigen Nostalgieboom und Erinnerungen an meine Kindheit, als ich dieses Spiel gespielt habe. 

Ty der junge tasmanische Tiger erlebt wohl die beste [b]Geschichte[/b], die das australische Outback je gesehen hat. 
Eines Tages begegnet Ty dem Bunyip-Ältesten, welcher ihm erzählt, wo dass Tys Verwandten und Artgenossen geblieben sind. Der böse Kausar namens Boss Cass wollte die fünf mystische Talismane in seinen Besitz bringen, um über das Land zu herrschen. Doch die tasmanischen Tiger machten ihm einen Strich durch die Rechnung, worauf hin er sie mit den Talismane in die Traumzeit verbannte. Die Talismane wurden dabei jedoch über das ganze Land verstreut. 
Ty erhält bei der Rettung seiner Familie Unterstützung von deinem Freund dem Koala, ein unglaublich guter Wissenschaftler mit dessen Maschine er die Talismane finden kann, um seine geliebten zu retten. Diese Maschine benötigt jedoch sogenannte Amulettsteine, um betrieben zu werden und so macht sich Ty nun auf die Suche danach. 

Das [b]Gameplay[/b] verteilt sich auf mehrere grosse Levels, welche alle durch eine Oberwelt miteinander verbunden sind. 
Jedes Gebiet ist sehr abwechslungsreich gestaltet und unterscheidet sich stark zu den anderen. Urwald, Schnee, Wasser, Strand, fast alle Szenarien wurden implementiert und jedes ist detailreich mit Vegetation, Tieren, Felsformationen, Gebäuden und natürlich vielen Rätseln gefüllt. Immer gibt es neue Mechaniken, welche das Gameplay auffrischen, sei dies das Reiten auf einem gigantischen Bullen, das geniessen einer Wasserrutsche oder das bedienen eines Geschützes. 
Zu sammeln gibt es unglaublich viel. Jesdes Level hält Opale, Amulettsteine, goldene Zähnräder, duzende Bilderrahmen und Tys gefangene Freunde versteckt. 
Jedes dieser Items hat auch eine Bedeutung. So dienen Amulettsteine dem Spielvortschritt, Bilderrahmen um die Galerie freizuschalten und die Zahnräder um neue Bumerangs zu erhalten. 
Bumerangs sind neben zahlreichen Fähigkeiten, welche Ty zum Meisterathleten machen, die Hauptwaffen unseres Helden. Mit unzähligen Variationen wie einen Feuerrang, Eisrang, Aquarang usw. kämpft man sich durch die Levels und verklopft jeden Anhänger von Boss Cass. Von denen gibt es nach jedem Abschnitt auch eine grosse Variante, welche zwar relativ einfach zu besiegen sind, dennoch ganz schön Spass machen. 
Das beinah beste am Spiel ist die Art bzw. den Humor der Charaktere und den Charm, welche die Entwickler hineingesteckt haben. Unglaublich witzige Dialoge zieren das Spiel, auch wenn leider viele Witze ins deutsche übersetzt nicht mehr ganz so gut sind, wie sie ursprünglich wären. 

Der [b]Soundtrack sowie die Soundeffekte[/b] sind sehr gelungen. Die fetzige australische Musik untermalt jedes Level mit einer passenden Stimmung. Auch wenn nicht alle Titel einen Ohrwurm auslösen, sind sie dennoch überaus gut.

[b]Grafik[/b] ist natürlich für heutige Verhältnise weit unter dem Standard. Es ist ein altes Spiel und trotz leichten Verbesserungen wie Ambient Occlusion oder Bloom sieht das Spiel nur leicht besser aus, als das Original. 
Wiedergegeben wird das Spiel übrigens mit maximal 60fps. Trotzdem sieht das Spiel unglaublich stimmig aus und nach spätestens ein paar Minuten wird man vergessen, dass es schon weit mehr als ein Jahrzehnt alt ist. 

[b]Optionen[/b] fehlt es dem Spiel nicht. Grafik, Soundlautstärken, Untertitel ist alles einstellbar vertreten. Die Steuerung lässt sich leicht konfigurieren, d.h Tastenbelegungen sind fix jedoch hat man die Wahl zwischen Tastatur oder Controller und kann mehrere Presets nach belieben benutzen. Das komplette Spiel unterstützt mehrere Sprachen, sowohl Text als auch Ton ist komplett auf deutsch verfügbar. 

Die [b]Spielzeit[/b] läuft für Neuzugänger wie mich für die 100% inklusive [b]Steam Errungenschaften[/b] auf ca. 20 Stunden heraus. Man wird also eine Weile spass haben. 

[b]Performance (Problem?... Nein!)[/b]
Dies ist ein Problem, welches laut Recherche nur mich betroffen hat und ich auch nicht lösen konnte. Die Performance scheint ansonsten bei allen Nutzern gut zu sein. 
Trotz erfüllten Mindestanforderungen mit einer GTX 760 GPU und einer i7 4770k CPU und aktuellen Treibern, konnte ich das Siel nicht auf höchsten Einstellungen flüssig Spielen. Empfohlen wird eine GTX 770, was für solche Grafik eigentlich sehr hoch ist. 
Ich hatte das Problem, dass ich massive fps Einbrüche bis auf die niedrigen 10er hatte, sobald mehrere Gegenstände im nahen Sichtfeld angezeigt wurden. Nach deaktivieren der Kantenglättung und von SSAO sowie Bloom wurde dies zwar besser, drops hatte ich jedoch immer noch bis auf 20fps. Mir blieb schlussendlich nichts übrig, als die Grafikeinstellungen bis auf die Sichtweite komplett ins Minimum zu stellen, wodurch sich meine Probleme praktisch lösten. Wirklich schlechter sah das Spiel dadurch aber nicht aus. Ich lasse dieses Problem jetzt nicht in meine Spielewertung infliessen. 

[b]Fazit[/b]
TY the Tasmanian Tiger ist ein grandioses altes 3D Jump 'n' Run für alle Fans und liebhaber dieses Genres. Das Spiel zeugt von unvergleichlichem australischem Humor und bietet die volle Länge Spass beim Zocken. Es ist mit einem Preis von momentan 15 CHF/Euro perfekt im Preis-Leistungsverhältnis und ein Must-Play für alle, welche sich von einem guten 3D Platformer mit grossen, detailierten Levels und abwechslungsreichem Gameplay begeistern lassen. 
Von meiner Seite aus eine [b]klare Kaufempfehlung[/b]!

30763986.review:
Well, this starts my review... the 11'th negative review for this game on Steam.

I'm not expecting most people to agree with me, but I think that anyone who is thinking about purchasing this game should also know some of the issues with it. The port is actually really good, I mean, I never played the original game, but it runs well on my modern gaming PC. The game is actually pretty fun, and I 100%'d the first few levels. I'm not saying you won't like the game, but I'm saying it's not for everyone. I personally liked the game, but found it to be repetitive in the later levels.

If you're expecting anything more than a few hours of platforming fun, you're going to be disappointed. The bosses are mind-numbingly easy, the levels are cool but most of them are too similar, the core gameplay isn't really spectacular, it's okay. However, if you are nostalgic for this game in any capacity, you might as well pick it up. In fact, even if you aren't, it's still the highest rated game on Steam.

Just buy it. If you don't like the first 30 minutes of the game, you won't like the rest of it, and you can just refund it.

A PS2 (and now PC) version of Banjo-Kazooie caught my interest, but sadly is not as polished and fun as it predecessor, being good at best.
So why I am recommending this? Because I have a good time playing it, even not taking getting achievements into account (I kinda care for achievements pretty much), and this is what counts, right?
TY is pretty dull protagonist, lacking charisma, having stupid dialogues and because of his australian slang, he sounds often like an idiot, to be honest. But what game lack in hero presentation, makes up with fun gameplay with bright ideas, nice soundtrack and well-designed stages.
Both installments of Sonic Adventure are available on Steam and are better in my opinion (especially SA2), so if you haven't played any of the titles mentioned here, check SA first. But if you've finished both SA installment and you still want to play some 3D action platformers, look no further than TY (at least before Yooka-Laylee comes out, but it will be more expensive).
I treat TY as an appetizer before Yooka & Laylee and I'm not disappointed.

30678839.review:
Whoa boy, we're back in the Australian Outback again!

Ty the Tasmanian Tiger fits into the same niche as great titles such as "Banjo Kazooie", "Jack and Daxter: The Precursor Legacy", and "Croc: Legend of the Gobbos". In the game, you play as the Thyracine named Ty, who stumbles upon a cave of paintings depicting the destruction of the Outback by one known as Boss Cass, a Cassowary, who threatens to revert the Outback to prehistoric times, putting cold-blooded lizards at the top of the food chain once again. It is up to Ty and his band of fauna to put a stop to the stubborn bird's plans.

Having sunk 15 hours into the game, I was able to complete the game at 100%, including all Steam achievements (and this was at a relaxed pace, and knowing what to do due to previous experience).  I would say that a newcommer to the series would be able to beat the game to 100% in 24 hours. For the nice price of twelve dollars USD, I would say that it is money well spent, moving up and about the Australian Outback with a small Arsenal of boomerangs.

Parental Advisory: Ty's girlfriend is a Dingo, whilist Ty is a Thylacine. Interspecies relationships exist in this game. Be forewarned. If your child plays this game and expresses wanton for interspecies relationships, sit them down and explain why such things are frivilous.

Story: 7/10 
You know what you are doing most of the time and you are given direction. Not a page turner.

Gameplay: 9.5/10 
Better than most Collectathon controls. Would request changing boomerang switching to mousewheel, but is impossible.
Game progression is great. Technorangs can be very useful, especially if you are not quite so good at the game.

Graphics: 9/10 
I've seen more visually impressive PS2 Graphics. The port does an excellent job cleaning up polygons, though.

Music: 10/10
Really puts you into the mood for crocodile wranglin'

Replayability: 6/10
You may go back to get the last cogs or last picture frames, but no way in hell are you doing it again.

Overall Score: 9/10

Ty has aged very poorly. Even compared to games for the PS1 like Spyro and Crash Bandicoot the terrible level design still stands out. But... I had fun. It's clearly made on a shoestring budget, and for what was Krome's big break game it holds up fine enough. It's a bit obtuse, but I didn't hate it. 

If there was a way to give a kind of middle of the road review I would. I didn't grow up with Ty, and thus this is a fresh experience. I liked it well enough to play through it. It's got a lot of charm, especially considering a know a few Australians who really do say stuff like "Struth" and "Banza." So, if you're looking for a game that's kind of interesting, if a lot sloppy, Ty isn't a bad choice. 

And maybe they'll bring the sequels back too, which I've heard are supposed to be better.

Ahh yes, TY the Tasmanian Tiger, the game I've always wanted to play as a child and never got around to buying it. When I found out that a remastered version was headed to Steam, I was immediately overcome with joy. Once I sat down and began playing, I instantly regretted the poor choice I made as a child.

Pros
+Customizable graphics
+Controller support 
+Collect-a-thon (collecting various items such as thunder eggs, rainbow scales, golden cogs, etc.)
+Fun (and some challenging) puzzles
+Ability to save at any given time
+In-depth info screen
+Several different worlds to explore, each with a unique theme.
+Decent voice work
+Awesome soundtrack
+Simple tutorial level

Cons
-Some exploration can be time consuming (specially when it comes to getting 100% in each level: bilbys and opals are particularly challenging)
-Like all platformers, percision is key when jumping, jumping at the wrong second or slightly tilting the control stick (or mouse) can be disasterous.
-Some of the repetitive music could possibly get on someone's nerves.

29938551.review:
A fantastic port of one of the underrated standouts among the character-driven 3D platformers in the PS2 era.  This is everything an HD conversion should be, as not only does it feature properly enhanced graphics for modern systems, but load times are blisteringly fast and both menus and controls have been significantly improved over the original release.

TY itself is an easy but enjoyable platform game with well-designed levels, tons of visual flair, and lots of stuff to collect.  There isn't much story and the game isn't terribly innovative, but it's crafted with enough polish to satisfy casual gamers looking for a few laughs over 5-10 hours depending on your acquisition  OCD.  It was infamous for rather twitchy controls which normally would not age well, but this update has addressed most of the serious control and camera problems.  I highly recommend playing with a mouse, though you'll need to tone the sensitivity way down if you value your sanity.

My major gripe is that the boss battles can be very confusing and have no continuity with either the character development or the story, but thankfully there's not many of them and they're not terribly difficult.  There are also some jumping puzzles that require pixel precision (par for the course in the early 90's).

Overall, well worth the entry fee and a wonderful nostalgia kick updated by the original development label.  Every classic game should receive this kind of treatment if a re-release is being considered.

TY 2 is currently in development, and hopefully the entire trilogy will be released eventually.  I eagerly await the next installment!

29718849.review:
I first played this game way back in the day on the Playstation 2 before i could even understand english (It´s my second language). However that didn´t stop me from fully enjoying the game, it´s very simplistic and someone that don´t even play video games on a regular basis can play this game with no problems.

The Story:

This story takes place in Australia and you play as a Tasmanian tiger called Ty. Ty´s family has been trapped in the spirit world by the evil Boss Cass (The Main Villain of the story). It is now up to Ty to save his family and friends from Boss Cass who wants power from the ancient Talismans that trapped Ty´s family in the spirit world. You will be travelling across multiple different enviroments of Australia to find them including the forests, the outback and the great barrier reef. Along the way you will be facing Boss Cass´ goons that include kangaroos, frill lizards and blue tongue lizards as well as mini bosses like a bull, a cyborg shark and a massive mountain monster.

The Gameplay:

The gameplay isn´t too advanced. Combat consists of you throwing boomerangs and techno boomerangs at foes as well as biting them. You will also be gliding, swiming and jumping a lot since the game is a 3D platformer after all. In each level there are different tasks that include finding and saving your friends, collecting all opals and collecting all golden cogs that will unlock technorangs. Each level all have a main quest that can be something like escorting someone to safety, finding lost children or finding someone of interest.

The characters:

Ty: Ty is the main character and he is the typical hero and doesn´t really have to much to say but still have a rich personality and is very "Australian"

Maurie: Maurie is your guide throughout the game. He tells a lot of jokes and introduces you to each level and gives you a general idea of what you´ll be facing in the levels.

Julius: Julius is a tech genius and is the character that allows you to travel to different levels and gives you the technorangs if you collect enough golden cogs.

Boss Cass: Boss Cass is the antagonist of the game and uses his minions to fight you. He doesn´t have a lot of depth besides that he wants the talismans to elliminate the tasmanian tigers.


The design:

This game has incredible design. The atmosphere is incredible and you feel like you´re in Australia and the music only solidifies this. The graphics have a special charm that you will find in other games from that time as well. I had no performance issues with the game and it ran smoothly. I also did not encounter any bugs or glitches so kudos to Krome Studios.


Generally this is the game that i remember from my childhood and i am so thankful that they managed to bring the magic of the game over to PC from Consoles.

29705013.review:
After replaying the whole game again after it left early access to become the full version, I'll now rewrite my review, whether that changes much or not, to represent the final product.

Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is a game for fans of platformers. It's a classic collectathon game with not a lot of emphasis on story or graphics. In terms of difficulty, it's quite frankly a game for kids, as it is for the most part very easy to progress through. Somes bosses may stump you unlike the rest of the game due to a lack of guidance combined with very unobvious tasks you must do (Particularly the Fluffy's Fjord level).

For the most part, Ty's level design is done quite well. Many levels are very linear, but with enough twists and turns to make them fun to play, while several are very large and open. One might call the larger levels rather empty, but this is expected given the limitations of the time this game was made in. So for what they did accomplish, these levels are still impressive, and even beautiful in some cases.

Graphics are obviously nothing to write home about. They're kept relatively basic as the game is focused on gameplay instead. None of the textures, effects, etc are pixilated or unnecessarily blurry, so they're really not a cause for concern. Lighting and shadows are nicely done in the remaster, and the remastered version allows you to see things MUCH further away than in the original, which makes for some amazing views and nice spotting points to search the map for collectables you might be missing.

Ty the Tasmanian Tiger's soundtrack is excellent, featuring mostly great songs and some that are just downright amazing (Two Up). There are a couple odd balls, mainly the boulder minigame theme, but you'll rarely find yourself immediately hating a song (Only after you've spent an hour trying to find the last opal).

The occasional quirk you might encounter might include the infra-rang sound effect or camera trouble. The infra-rang is just down-right annoying, and as for the camera, there are settings you can use to adjust it closer to your liking. If you still have trouble after that, it's probably more your fault than the game's, being that I myself never had problems with the camera as bad as others might describe.

Regarding bugs or oddities of any sort, I've found only two things so far while playing the game. I'm unsure whether this is the game's fault or not, but it seems to have potential for slight incompatibilities with some computer settings. I changed power usage settings at some point before finishing my second playthrough found that the lighting effects were too strong and some particle effects had boxes around them. While these errors are not at all severe and won't distract you much, they are still errors nonetheless. However on the level "Lyre, Lyre Pants on Fire", there is a possibly gamebreaking bug. It is possible you may comb the level and still be missing a few opals. This is because there Y coordinates can glitch out (Or are just flat out incorrect, I'm not sure), making them impossible to reach and/or find. Fear not though, for they can also glitch out again by reloading the level (Or this is Krome's idea of a fix), and spawn in a respawned crate, from which you can acquire the missing opals. Finally the weird landscape at the end of "Beyond the Black Stump" isn't bugged out or anything. It's just lazyness or a lack of time for polishing.

For what the game is trying to be, it's very well crafted. It's certainly nothing less than at least a descent game. If you enjoy platformers, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is definitely a title to pick up.
