29552516.review:
TY, mate! You took your time!

TY the Tasmanian Tiger. Where does one even begin with this beauty? My earliest gaming memories are of TY, exploring the Barrier Reef, and searching for lost koala children in the snowy mountian tops. I'll go more in depth about this little ripper.

[h1] STORY	[/h1]


TY the Tasmanian Tiger has a simple story: 

You are TY, the last of the Thylacines (that's "Tasmanian Tigers", by the way). 

Your family disappeared years ago, lost in a dimension known as "The Dreamtime", after the nefarious Boss Cass, a cassowary with dreams of world domination, sought to steal the five magical talismans which open a portal to said dimension. Luckily, they were spread across Austrailia after the Thylacines were lost, much to Cass' dismay.

But how do you learn about all this? Well, one day, when you were playing out in the forest with your Bilbie friends, you fell into a hole in the ground and met with a mystical Bunyip Elder. He told you the whole story, and so, with Murray the Cockatoo and Julius the Koala by your side, you set out to save your family.

[h1] GRAPHICS	[/h1]

The graphics in this game are truly something to behold, even for a game like this. The truly breathtaking, sandy plains of the Outback, the lush rainforests, the beautiful beaches. If you're looking for a game with beautiful, cartoonish levels, give this one a try for sure.

[h1] GAMEPLAY	[/h1]

The gameplay is some of the best I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I'll lay this one out in sections.

[b] LEVELS	[/b]

The levels are so beautifully thought out, some wide open, with lots of area to cover, and even more places to search for collectables, and some narrow, but still very large, leaving multiple pathways for you to explore and many areas to visit and revisit, making for a great reason to backtrack and play the level again.

[b] PROTECTION	[/b]

To protect yourself, you're armed with a pair of wooden boomerangs, which are only one pair of a large number of 'rangs that you'll be able to unlock throughout the course of the game, as well as your good old pearly white teeth. Bite and 'rang your way through those enemies!

[b] COLLECTABLES	[/b]

The main section of gameplay is searching for collectables. These include:

Thunder Eggs:
By the end of this game, you'll have seen so many of these sparkling gemstones that you won't be able to think of anything else. They're the main collectable in the game, and are neccessary to access and defeat each area's boss level and acquire the magical talismans.

Golden Cogs:
These items will be necessary for the 100% completion, and to unlock new boomerangs to use in the many levels of this game. After you collect so many, a new boomerang is added to your arsenal.

Opals:
Opals are the rings, coins, wumpa fruit or gems of the TY universe, a whole 300 to collect per level. Don't you worry, though! They're not too hard to find, if you know where to look! Collecting all of them will... well, I'll let you figure it out.

[b] CONTROLS	[/b]

The controls are pretty decent, when you use a Keyboard and Mouse, but I recommend using a controller. Either way, both styles can be fully customised, allowing you to find what controls work best for you.

TY can do basic functions like running, jumping and attacking, as well as being able to learn to swim and glide later on. The movement is quite smooth, and the jumping will almost never be a problem for you.

[b] QUESTS	[/b]

All of the aforementioned "Thunder Eggs" are acquired via a sort of mission system. In every level, there are a number of Thunder Eggs to collect, each obtainable through either completing a time attack mission, doing jobs for people, finishing minigames and collecting them whilst traversing each level, as well as saving your Bilbie friends (mentioned earlier, who raised TY after his family.

[h1] CONS	[/h1]

As great as the game is, there are some problems with it.

-It can be confusing at times, not knowing where to go now and then.
-One boss, namely [spoiler] Fluffy	[/spoiler], can be pretty confusing if you don't know what to do. It's not made very clear at all.
-LENNY THE LYRE BIRD
-[spoiler] Beyond the Black Stump, and Rex marks the Spot	[/spoiler] are not very memorable or enjoyable levels, imo.

[h1] FINAL THOUGHTS	[/h1]

Overall, TY is a fun, charming little game that a lot of people can just pick up and play with little to no issue, and honestly, if you like character-based collectathons, you should definitely purchase this game.

You Ripper/10

29394476.review:
A run-of-the-mill collectathon platformer that's a bit like if you mixed a bunch of Sonic OCs with Mad Max Kidz. A very, very Australian game, to the point where if it wasn't actually made by Australians it would come off as grotesquely racist. The main character, Ty, speaks almost entirely in stereotypically Australian exclamations like some kind of tourism board mascot, which given that everyone else in the game speaks mostly-normally leads to him coming off as a touch surreal, like he was originally written as a silent protagonist who had dialogue hastily added into conversations held more at him than too him.

Story-wise, the game is as thin as it gets. I almost get the impression that the game was based on some sort of Saturday Morning Cartoon, the way the backstory is vaguely alluded to, characters come and go like we should know them already, and side characters go through cliche story arcs at breakneck pace. It's not that I didn't know what was going on - everything about the story was incredibly by-the-numbers - but it felt like somebody wrote a story twice as long and had it edited down.

Gameplay is basically passable, if annoying. You only gain two new moves throughout the game, aside from your ever-growing collection of boomerangs with increasingly redundant functions. The boomerangs themselves are fairly clumsy to use, despite being your primary weapon, as their range is extremely vague and their targetting is inconsistent, leading to many situations where you can throw one at an enemy five feet away and it'll whiz harmlessly past him and leave you unarmed for the next few seconds. However, the game's difficulty is almost nonexistent - the hardest achievement in the game is the one where you have to lose all your lives - largely due to Ty getting nearly 10 seconds of mercy invincibility every time he takes damage, meaning it honestly takes effort to lose a life to a single threat.

Ultimately, though, the game is honestly inoffensive. It was a functional timekiller, but I'm not going to give it a recommendation on the grounds that I wouldn't actually suggest anyone else go out of their way to play it. It's not bad, but it's hardly anything good either.

29242581.review:
I finished the game in two play sessions. Mainly because I've played the game when it was still on Gamecube.

Now that I've beaten the game, I'm just going to go over the pros and cons:

+ The music never gets old, even with the loop. That says something about the sound design.
+ The gameplay is actually solid for a collectathon title. Hell, even the swimming controls were pretty good, from a genre that generally has crappy water levels...
+ The dialogue is witty, and screams Austrilia. Also, NEVER play Ty without sound, because you might miss some of the adlibs the characters make separate of the subtitles.

~ While not a major concern, the game doesn't run all that well on low end PCs. If you are worried about performance, just reduce all graphics options to their absolute minimum, then lower the resolution. Lowering the resolution only shrinks the screen, not the resolution itself.

- The controls can feel floaty at times, and it may take some time getting used to.
- If you end up missing anything in a level, it is a pain to find out what exactly you missed. Fortunately, every level except the first can be completed in one go, so don't feel as if you need to backtrack later in the game.
- I didn't test the game with Keyboard and mouse, but the game wasn't designed with this in mind. If you want the best possible experince, you have to play with a controller.

Now, let's get the rest of the series on Steam, and I'll be sure to creamate those games when they come out! (In other words, I'm going to 100% them)

29199874.review: To anyone who has never heard of Ty The Tasmanian Tiger, this game may not be the your cup of tea. The main reason is because the camera controls are a bit hard to get used to which does makes some difficult platforming areas and the game does come acrossed as a bit, "childish" or maybe "unoriginal." Why? *SPOILER WARNING* The plot in a nutshell is Ty has to find all 5 of these Talismans to save his family from an alternate dimension while the antagonist is also tryhing to find the Talismans for personal game. However, growing up playing the first two games in the series on the XBox, I LOVE seeing this franchise get remastered! It gave me the chance to 100% one of my favorite childhood games and let me see my sister actually go out of her way to play a video game. While it may be another platformer that follows Super Mario 64's level system where each level has multiple key items you need to progress, the boomerage mechanic and unique feel this game has makes it worth a shot.

A super solid, well done, easy to play remastered port of the original Ty the Tasmanian Tiger game. I was initially a little worried about not having an Xbox controller to play this with but after 30 seconds of playing with my keyboard and mouse, my worries were dispelled. The controls are stupidly easy to learn and feel great with the keyboard and mouse. This game is just as much fun now as it was back in the day and the only thing I can complain about is some of the models look dated and chunky, but for a game made back in 2002, I'm willing to let it slide, especially considering that most of the game still looks wonderful with its crisp colours and gorgeous levels.

Whether you were a fan of the games growing up, or just want a good old-school 3D platformer, I can without hesitation reccomend this game to you, especially for its relatively low pricetag.

28967385.review:
Now, allow me to provide a little backstory. I got this game back when I was roughly 9? 10 years old? Back then, it was around the time the PS2 era had hit a spike in popularity, so naturally, I got this game as a Christmas gift, and I fell in love with it. Maybe it's because furry animals are a guilty pleasure of mine, but that's a story for a different day.

Naturally, when I saw this game was on sale on Steam, nostalgia got the better of me, and I bought it in a heartbeat. Playing it as an adult, as one would expect, is certainly different from how it was when I was a kid, and that's putting it lightly. This is both a good and a bad thing, and I'll go ahead and break it down so I don't waste more of your time with unimportant backstory.

[h1]Gameplay. 6/10[/h1]

It's... About what you would expect from a platformer on a PS2 at the time. You jump around, collect stuff, complete objectives to move on to the next level, kill enemies, and has some side missions on the side. It doesn't necesarrily deviate from the 3D platformers at the time like Spyro, Crash Bandicoot and other games,  so if you're looking for something revolutionary, this definitely isn't it. 

I would say that in terms of gameplay, this game is pretty close to Banjo Kazooie, in the sense that most of the game revolves around collecting stuff to get more stuff. 

This isn't to say that it's BAD, or COMPLETELY unoriginal. One thing that does set this game apart is a few things, such as replacing double jumping with gliding, using Boomerangs as weapons rather than fire or, well, your fists, and the fact that there are very few levels with "unique" mechanics that change the gameplay a bit.  

There are times, however, where the objective is not clearly communicated. For example, in one level, you are supposed to use coconuts to get across some quicksand. This is not properly explained or hinted it unless you decided to just randomly throw some boomerangs around. The game stops nearly all hand holding about halfway through, so if you don't understand how to do something, you're on your own in that regard. 

I give the gameplay a solid 6/10. It's nothing really special or out of the ordinary, but it's by no means boring. The game has just enough for you to do and kill so you won't be left wandering aimlessly and figuring out what to do. 

[h1]Story. 3/10. [/h1]

The story is cheesy, that's all there is to say about it. It's a pretty by the book "you're the chosen hero that has to save the world" scenario that's typical of games around this era. 

The story also relies on a lot of ex-machina scenarios (An antagonist showing up when you least expect it, falling into a hole at the very beginning and finding out the entire backstory completely out of the blue, and so on), so at times, it does feel like things happen out of the blue without any reason. 

Really, there isn't much to say about the story. It's fairly predictable despite things happening seemingly out of no where, character development is near enough nonexistent, and... That's it. 

[h1] Graphics. 5/10[/h1]

For a PS2 game, the graphics aren't bad. They aren't GREAT, but they aren't abysmal, either. Much like its gameplay, it's what you would expect from a PS2 era platformer: low renders and flat angles. 

At times, the game does feel a little empty, but that's only in the first couple of levels. Nothing is really boring to look at, and aesthetically, the game is pretty pleasing. You have rainforests, snow areas and ocean areas, and each level has pretty good lighting and scenery that gives it the feel it's going for.

[h1] Overall: 6/10[/h1]

The game is definitely much better as a child than as a fully grown adult. While it does have enough to keep someone interested in terms of gameplay, and it doesn't really get stale, it suffers from playing things a little too safe. Nothing about it is extraordinary or revolutionary in any way, which isn't necesarrily a bad thing, but it makes the game ultimately forgettable. 

I recommend this game for younger audiences, since I am sure that younger folks will find a lot more enjoyment out of it than older. If you are an older person looking for a good PS2 platformer, I can't really say that this is what you're looking for. If you want to try it out, by all means, go for it-- it's not a bad game by any means. There are just other PS2 games that do what this game does but better.

One of my first PS2 games I had when I was little. I still love this game today, the TY series has always been a fun adventure game for me. The gameplay is simple, jump and collect things, yes this is a collectiphon.  

 • 9 levels.
 • 72 Thunder Eggs, 8 in each level.
 • 90 Golden Cogs to find, 10 in each level.
 • 2700 Orbies, 300 in each level.
 • 45 Bilbies, 5 in each level.
 • 25 Rainbow Scales, all of them are found in the hub world.
 • 373 Picture Frames, scattered throughout every level.
 • 12 different Boomerangs.
 • Time Attacks in each level.

This game still remains to be one of my favorite adventure games to play. If you want a good collectiphon, this is a perfect game for you.

8+1/10. One extra point for hitting my nostalgia hard.

28523333.review:
Wow, where do I start?

I remember playing this game as a kid, and it by far was one of my favorites. The fact its a PC port now makes me so happy that I as a fully grown man, actually freaked out in excitement. I got the game shortly after it came out of Early Access as a small present from a friend.

This game is just as amazing as I remember it and have loved playing through it again, this time armed with a good head on my shoulders so I know what to do.

This game isnt hard, I wont lie, its actually pretty easy to beat. Though if you like treasure hunting and collecting, this is the game for you. The core of this game basically is trying to 100% it, which takes some legit effort in the end. The story is honestly not the best in the world, but it doesnt need much more than a motivation to get you going anyway. The short version is: Grab Thunder Eggs, Snag Talismans, Put your boomarang up Boss Cass's *** and you win. The rest is you scowering the land for the rest of the collectables to 100% the game and prove your weight in salt.

Some things I should note *potentially light spoils btw* 

-Grab those golden cogs!
-You will never use the Infarang unless you plan on 100%ing this game.
-The Kaboomarang is LUDICROUSLY Over powered.
-The Doomarang is useless tbh due to limited range and the fact it only serves as a trophy of you beating the boss
-Collecting all the rainbow scales doubles your HP (it helps if you're clumsy)
-The Megarang is kinda pointless because its bounce range is very short


Something else that should be noted:

The bosses are hard if you dont know what to do. Sometimes its not clear because they rely on concepts you havent worked with before which is a BIG negative in some sense. The only one you get remotely told roughly what to do is the 3rd boss, and even then its not super helpful.

However, once you figure out what to do, well.... the bosses just basically become a click and survive fest. Not much challenge to it. This causes kinda a rather jagged dificulty spike in the game. Which simply can be annoying untill the awnser staring you in the face is realized. For those who wanna know:

[spoiler] To deal with Bull, you have to bait him into running into the large mound pillars, these are presumably termite dens or some kind of fire ant nest. You have to do this 4-6 times before he drops. [/spoiler] 

[spoiler] To deal with ye old shark you have to knock the chum into the water, and while he's distracted (i reccomend knocking two buckets in so he will be distracted long enough just in case you goof) you go under water and shoot the air tanks to get them to float up. Once they do hit them with the Flamearang to explode them (this will not work with any other Rang) while he chews on them. You only need to do this 3 times [/spoiler]

[spoiler] To deal with Mecha-Yeti whatchamacallit you have to burn all the fur off with the Flamearang, the hitbox for the torso does NOT extend to the back from my testing, you MUST hit it from the front and even then it can be a little wonky sometimes. Once this is done the pilot lights on the ground will come on. You must THROW your flamearang through the flames so that it causes the rang to burst into flames and hit the Mech. Do this a few times and then it will sink into the water. You will get a cutscene of fluffy, then switch to your Freezyrang to freeze it into the water (just basically keep spamming the throw button at it) and you will emerge victorius. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] For Boss cass it doesnt seem straightforward at first. So heres some help: The first thing you do is freeze the flame throwers (watch out there is literally NO safe spaces when you first drop in) and then you actually bite them to blow them up. Destroy all 12-16 or however many there are on the deck and the force fields will drop on the pannels. Destroy these pannels by tossing your rangs at them and basically just take the hit from the flame throwers because honestly they dont seem to turn off for very long. When down in the lower sector of the mech take out your Flamarangs and destroy all the ice looking cores and their wires (you have to hit each core twice!) till the head of the machine for some reason explodes off and you get a cut scene of Sly turning all good on you and giving you a family heirloom known as the Doomarang. Toss it into the glowing green throat chute and begin what I honestly have to declare as: [i] THE MOST LAME ENDING TO A BOSS FIGHT EVER!!!! [/i] You dont run around and fight cass. You literally have to sit through and fly a rather overly sensitive boomarang through a twisty and turney gauntlet before ultimatly you reach the end and it somehow blows everything to smithereens. Congrats you beat the game! The ending cutscene will play and you get to do as you please afterward [/spoiler]

Now that you got past all those spoilers on how to beat the bosses if you get stuck.

[h1] My final verdict on this game: [/h1]

The game doesnt have much story to it, I wont lie. And what it does have isnt greatly explained in the game.

Its got solid controls and responsive actions that feel good to play on my Xbox controller (despite the fact I orginally played this on PS2)

There are some glitches that do occur, but nothing seriously game breaking, Except for one where: [spoiler]  the miniboss in Cass's Crest who would happen to be that bat lady, I landed in the lava and tossed a rang at the same time, so I was shot back to land at the same time the bats attacked me and I grabbed my rang after it hit something all while being on 1 HP. This caused my game to softlock in a situation where I presume it canceled the death animation so I was set as "dead" but since the death animation was cancelled by me grabbing my Rang (the bats should have finished me off while i was in a get up animation too) it just caused some kind of error where it didnt reset me back at the last dunny. [/spoiler]

There is some humor in this if you like that sorta stuff and its not out of place thankfully

This game for one has what most games these days tend to lack: An atmosphere. It actually has a feeling to it that no other game can have besides its sequal Ty 2. And that is honestly something thats hard to do so props to Krome

The game has the old time PS2 era charm where the dialouge is [i] REALLY clunky, and I mean almost cringe worthy at times [/i] 

However, despite all the negatives and the sort it has alot of positives and quite frankly, the game has aged really well. The gameplay is amazing for a port, I honestly dont think I would be able to tell a differance between the orginal and the port by control responsiveness. There are some animation quirks in the port and of course the occasional glitch but otherwise, this is an amazing game still in the end of 2016 and brings back alot of good nistolgia. 

Plus they released a cover photo for the amazing sequal Ty 2: Bush Rescue. Which I am [b] HYPED [/b] for and will Buy it the second its ready.

I must say, Krome really did outdo themselves with this port, and im looking forward to the sequal which was the game that defined my childhood and honestly with the Bunyips and all the boomarangs it really got me into a polethera things ranging from actual boomarangs to mecha anime and robot fighting (i was also a big transformers armada fan as a kid) 

So credit where credit is due. Thumbs up krome.

[u] But also I MUST give flak where its due, and I just have to say: Ty 3 was the game that ruined my childhood. The game took such a left turn with the atmosphere and story to the point where I straight up hated it. Its Gunyip segments were kinda confusing, the color pallete went from vibrant to dull, the story was god awful, it destroyed everything Ty 2 built upon, the ending was just tragicly bad and honestly kinda weird, and to top it all off the boomarang customization system while inovative kinda just seemed out of place. However, I doubt you will see this, but I just had to say it. [/u]

27781071.review:
[u]Note: This review is mostly meant to justify the category I'm suggesting for the Steam Awards which I'm calling "Nostalgia Lives!" soooo LONG POST AHEAD! (TL;DR at the bottom)[/u]

[h1]NOSTALGIA LIVES![/h1]
At 6 years of age, while my mother was manning a food stall with her siblings at a funfair, my cousins and I explored the foyer where Microsoft was marketing and showing off the original Xbox. Of the many games they set up to let players try out for free, Halo was a staple and of course my cousins brought me to play it. 

But right next to Halo was another console station, where an older boy was manoeuvring a strange orange rat-creature through wooden bridges and collecting red glowing balls. Not to mention, the rat thing was throwing something that whacked green lizards and flew right back to him. It was outright fascinating. I got my chance to play after watching the boy. As a child of that age, I didn't fully understand what to do, where to go, or even [i]how[/i] to play it.. but I had fun. A bit too much fun, in fact - I spent the rest of the day at the foyer, testing out all the games but ultimately coming back to the orange rat thingummy.

I was 7 when my parents gifted me an Xbox of my own. Along with Halo and Star Wars, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was part of the 'Console + 3-game bundle' they were offering way back then, and you can imagine the absolute JOY I felt when I recognised the character on the cover of the game case - it was the orange rat! Whose name I then understood as Ty, who is a Tasmanian Tiger (which is extinct in the real world. Thanks mankind :c). Needless to say, for the next 6 to 7 years of my life and ownership of the Xbox, I always went back to TTTT, even when I wasn't able to buy the sequels.

My Xbox took its last breath in 2009, the same year I began living without console gaming. Yeah, I went to PC some time later, but never really played any games (I didn't know what Steam was back then). Fast forward to 2016, more mature and having a Steam game or two under my belt, random memories popped up and I decided "Hey, let's search that game I always played as a kid.." So I did. *scroll...scroll...scroll...* 

That's when I saw it. "...as of March 2016, TTTT being remastered for Steam". HOLY MERRY MOTHER OF JOSEPH. MY CHILDHOOD WAS COMING BACK.

Immediately searched for their Facebook page, reading through all their updates regularly. It was just sheer excitement! And the best part? It released while I was in AUSTRALIA, the HOME of Ty (p.s I was sitting in Parliament as a guest when I bought the game. Lel). The child in me pretty much took over.

When I finally flew back home 2 days later, sleep was nowhere in existence; I spent the entire night playing through all the levels and worlds, collecting every single thing I didn't collect befoer, and most importantly [i]savouring every bit of detail I first saw as that little child at the foyer[/i]. I was even happier when I got to the final world and boss, because that was the one thing I never got to do before my Xbox died. Simply... Simply magical... 

And now I hear they're planning to remaster the other two games? Krome Studios is fulfilling the wishes of the child in me. I'm elated. Excited. Grateful. Insertotherwordshere. Just.. thank you so much, Krome, for bringing back our childhood!




TL;DR = Had this game with original Xbox. Super happy when they remastered for Steam. I'm nominating it for a "Nostalgia Lives!" Award. c:

27304662.review:
The nostalgia is real, an old favourite of mine from the PS2. The dev team has worked so hard to not only bring the game back, but also updated almost everything about it. The Graphics have been updated and foliage increased, sounds are crisp, clear and not delayed and it works so well on PC.

+ No input lag
+ No audio compression
+ Beautiful graphics
+ Any hitches are noted and mentioned by the devs
+ Patches are frequent and detailed
+ M&KB can be used if you prefer

- Cutscenes are in the games original resolution so it is massively compressed, unfortunately there is no way to improve these as they no longer have the original files; however this was communicated by the devs themselves.

Devs provide frequent updates on the status of the overhaul (though they will be ending soon as the game is almost finished) and they listen to what we have to say in regards to improvements and even upcoming overhauls!

I recommend you use a controller while playing.

26758314.review:
[b]WARNING![/b] I do realise I have immense nostalgia for this game, so this review is biased towards those that love old school collectable and platforming games.


Short General Review: I can whole heartily say that this remake is one of the most faithful and respectful remakes I have ever played, and if you have a craving for an old-fashioned collectafon with solid platforming mechanics that has aged very well then you [b]NEED[/b] to buy this!

And just to further show my appreciation I nominated this game for the test if time award!

For people (like me) that played and love the original on console its great, but it does have some little problems that (while small) are noticeable.


The first problem I have noticed was the draw distance, with large maps like 'Ship Rex' and 'Rex Marks The Spot' the opals underwater require you to be rather close for them to pop in and yet other times can be seen preloaded from miles away. As this is a collectafon this can be quite concerning as there are 300 opals and missing one can cause me 20 -30 mins of in-depth back peddling and searching.


The second problem is that some smaller levels ('like snow worries' on high platforms) can allow you to view outside of the map into a black void. This probably due to the 16 : 9 aspect ratio and these maps weren't necessarily scaled for widescreen displays.


As you can see this is a very small list of complaints, and that is because I believe that these Devs have made something truly great and worth your time! All I can say is I wish the Devs my most thanks as it has rekindled something I thought was long dead from my childhood.



Keep Up the good work guys! And if your Team would ever make a Ty 2 remake I (and this reborn fanbase) wouldn't hesitate to pick it up!

26396580.review:
It's a fine, decent, average, playable 3D collectathon platformer. If you need one on PC?

Well, try playing Mario 64 and the Banjo games first, then come to this. Maybe start with Banjo Tootie if you want something weirdly morbid.

Anyway, there's not much to say. I wouldn't recommend this for 100% completionists because the placement of some of the opals (think coins from Mario) are really, horribly obscure and unsighposted, and you need to collect EVERY SINGLE ONE in order to get the corresponding thunder egg (Star/Jiggy). And leaving the level before collecting them all resets your collection. And there are 300, THREE HUNDRED, TROIS HUNDO, in each level. I once played through a level for about an hour trying to find the last 3, which were in a crate covered in snow on the side of a mountain with nothing else around it to make it an interesting area. What the criminy. 

But, it has snappy controls, a fun setting, interesting music, creative achievements, and... a couple cute characters. Mostly the fat parakeet guy. He's great.

No alarms and no surprises. It's a 3D collectathon platformer.

If you enjoyed this game as a kid, you'll love it today. I didn't realise that this was a remaster of the game so that was a nice surprise, especially the camera controls. When I tried to relive this game months ago on the PS2 I found the camera to be very finnicky compared to modern-day games, so it was hard to get back into. But they've really fixed it up in this version without making it feel like a totally different game.

If you've never played this game before but like the genre (or wanna get into the genre), this will make a nice addition to your library.

Only con I can really think of is that, if you're expecting a game on the scale of Crash or Spyro, then be aware that this is a short but sweet game. Nine basic levels, plus 3 bosses and then the final level, which is a gauntlet and then a boss. But the collectiables and objectives in this game will certainly make those levels last.

25773505.review:
Yes, awesome! 

I am glad Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was released on the PC for the first time ever! The game was released multiplatform on PS2, GC, and Xbox on the release date of September 10, 2002. The PS2 version was developed first then ported to Xbox and GC then released at the same date. I can't believe I missed out on this early access of Ty having a HD remaster on PC in Steam. While the Xbox ports were the best, the PC outshines all the ports! I should have bought the game back in March! But now I know and due to many updates the game now runs smoother and looks beautiful than before!

This is how a 14 year old cult-classic platforming game should be ported and released on PC! I love funny animals or you call them anthro animals. While the Crash Bandicoot series, Sly Cooper series, and Ratchet and Crank series are more well known and popular compare to Ty. Those who played those games will also enjoy Ty the Tasmanian Tiger series since it was remastered for the first time, which was needed for a long time. 

The Ty series were hard to access due to being on legacy six generation of home video game consoles: PS2, Xbox, and GC at that time. Each and every year, the games are becoming more rare and harder to find in physical hard copies in great condition. But, I am a proud owner of the original Ty trilogy on the original Xbox in mint condition. Because I still love the original Xbox and still play the console along with the exclusives, I've a decent collection of Xbox games with most that will never be released on PC or remastered to the current generation of consoles. 

Play as Ty and help his friends out to defeat the evil Boss Cass who threatens his Australia outback home!

The original ports of the game have bugs and some annoying things, but they're going to be fixed on this release.

I do hope the Ty series will be released for the PS4 and Xbox One as three games in one! Becausing playing a awesome game series like this on consoles is the true experience.

Amazing job, Krome Studios! I can't wait for Ty 2: Bush Resue to be next on the HD remaster! Ty 3 included too. The sequel is actually my most favorite in the series.

TY the Tasmanian Tiger might not be the strongest collectathon game (although I haven't played Banjo Kazooie in quite some time!) it is still a very enjoyable, solid game. 

It's worth noting that the early access badge that the game has is mostly for the PC port, which I found completely satisifactory in terms of controls. Performance was a little wonky at times, especially if you enable some of the newer settings recently added; however these will likely be addressed with time. The developers seem quite responsive and eager to continue to improve the game. They are also supposedly planning to port the second game, if this one sells well.

The game's combat is simple, mostly revolving around you choosing which type of boomerang for which situation. Exploring the maps is fun for the most part, however I wasn't a fan of the beach levels personally. 

The game's setting is rare so it is really enjoyable to hear Australian accents and see the wildlife that is more common there. 

All in all an enjoyable experience if you're looking for a good collectathon on PC and don't want to fret with emulators.

25686191.review:
You're likely here looking at reviews due to the game currently (at the time of this review) being in "Early Access." If you're curious about the game and its stability, read part 1. For the actual review - read part 2. Enjoy!

1) I'd like to immediately shut down those fears by saying this game has very few bugs or issues that will deter you from enjoying the game wholeheartedly. I recently 100%'d the game (excluding all achievements - but that's another beast) and only faced two 'big" glitches throughout the entire playthrough (which admittedly weren't all that troublesome). 

Without spoilers - the first was being stuck on a rock on a certain level where you ride a familiar-looking "friend" the entire level. I simply did the "charge" attack and ended up being stuck on top of a rock, but that was easily fixed by just reloading the level. The second one was a bit of a bummer, but not a big deal either. While watching the ending cutscene, my game crashed. Upon loading in, i spawned underneath the main hub only to fall for eternity (until exiting the level and going back in again). To me, these weren't very impactful to how much i enjoyed the game. Now for the review.

2) This game is fan-f***ing-tastic! I bought this due to nostalgia, as I'm sure most did - but even IF you never had a chance to play this game as a kid - I'd highly reccomend it. It has fun, rewarding gameplay that's not too difficult - but also adds in a challenge to each level by hiding collectables very cleverly. Sure, there are a few repeated tropes here and there (TY HELP ME I LOST MY 12 CHILDREN A >SECOND< TIME!), but nonetheless it's an amazing game to just sit down and relax with. Keep in mind that it has full controller support, which, in my opinion, is the best way to revisit this classic - but keyboard and mouse should do just fine as well if you aren't able to snag a reasonable gamepad. As for the graphics the devs are trying to improve upon - don't expect Battlefield 4 style'd graphics or anything - but in my experience they've been a nice touch. If you don't particularly enjoy them - there's always the option to switch them back to the good ol' pixels included in the original PS2 release (it's really not bad looking, if I had to be honest). 

All in all, this game is DEFINITELY worth a purchase if you're looking for something fun and relaxing to play, and can also satisfy those looking for a bit of a challenge (completionists who want to get ALL the things!). I would wholeheartedly reccomend it to just about everyone, and have already happily purchased this game for a friend or two already. 

Cheers!

[b][h1]Introduction:[/h1][/b]
Man, I cannot say how delighted I was to see this game up on Steam. I remember seeing Ty 4 up and whilst I was interested in getting (and I most certainly plan too) I couldn't help but think "I wish the earlier games were available." So it was a very welcome suprrise to see that the first is back (and that the 2nd and 3rd will be following along.)

[b][h1]Positives:[/h1][/b]
A+ Platformer: This is what alot of platformers should aspire to be what with how much fun it is, with its open world type enviroments and wide variety of enemies.

Hours of fun: This game is a pretty big collect-a-thon, which can leave alot to do if you want to reach 100% progress and get all the acheivements.

Acheivements: With this updated port comes a bunch of Steam Acheivements which is a very much welcome addition.

Solid Build: For an early access game, its already very well done. It doesn't experience any gamebreaking issues like random crashes or whatever, its very easily playable without too much problem.

[b][h1]Negatives:[/h1][/b]
Repetitive: Honestly, the game can feel a tad samey after awhile. Alot of the tasks to get Thunder Eggs and whatnot are pretty much the same across each level, which can be a bit of a killer to deal with.

FPS: The game seems to have rather large and unusual drops in FPS which can be a huge nuisance to deal with. It can in some cases cause the game to slow to a crawl which can really ruin the experience.

[b][h1]Closing Remarks:[/h1][/b]
The game is very well done so far. Whilst there is some work to be done, so far the game shows promise and I've full faith that Krome will deliver and polish this game to perfection. Got alot of hope for this game, and for ports of the next installments in the Ty series.

25505802.review:
[b]An opinionated review for a childhood gem.[/b]

[b]Gameplay[/b]: Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is a platform adventure game where the goal of each level is to find all the collectibles. This includes Opals, Golden Cogs(Which unlock boomerangs),Bilbies, and the lesser known portraits which if all are collected unlock a movie. If you 100% the game you will unlock a secret level. The game is easy as it's meant for kids but it still has many fun mechanics such as how the boomerangs interact with the enviroment. The combat consists of throwing 'rangs or biting your foes.

[b]Art[/b]: The game is old but it has an artistic charm and the new fancy effects of this remastered edition help bring it up to speed. What more can you expect? It's an old game meant to run on Xbox, Ps2, and Gamecube. As for as graphic fidelity, the devs are doing a splendid job updating it regularly with little tweaks here and there. Although they could replace textures to enhance it even more but it is fine.

[b]Music[/b]: Best soundtrack for a kid's game I have ever heard. This game nails the Australian theme by adding tunes that use authentic Australian instruments(or emulates them) that make each level a joy to play on. Plus the Australian accents on the characters is cheesy in a good way.

[b]Entertainment[/b]: You will 100% this game and be done with it maybe only returning for funsies or to compete in the leaderboards to see who can complete each level the fastest.

[b]Score[/b]: The nostalgia goggles are off. Ty is a kid's game that succeeds by giving an experience that is not totally braindead but charming and memorable. It is my favorite game from my own childhood near Crash,Ratchet,Spyro and Jak. It deserves to be listed there. The port is damned good too. Ty 2 and 3 will be an insta-buy for me.

[h1]4/5[/h1]      [h1]"YOU BEAUTY!"[/h1]

25381057.review: Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is a gaming treasure. This game falls in line with other platforming greats of the era, such as Spyro the Dragon, Crash Bandicoot, Super Mario 64, and others. Ty is special, just like those games are special. Ty has really fun controls, and neat abilities, which is key to an enjoyable platforming game. The characters are well voiced, the graphics are beautiful, the levels are very well designed, and I have to play a level through multiple times to find everything because of how well they are made. The story is interesting enough, and the music is just a joy to listen to. Do yourself a favor and experience this gem. Most of the reviews I read here are through a lens of nostalgia "I played this as a kid and enjoyed it then, so its good now."  I did NOT play Ty as a kid, so my review is unbiased from a nostalgia perspective, and is purely based on the game I see now in 2016. I have no idea why the devs are calling this early access. This game is more complete than most AAA titles, and its certainly more complete than its original console release, with better graphics, tighter controls, and more feature. -PR0XIDIAN

Beh, è Ty. Giocai questo gioco sulla ps2 ai tempi della sua prima uscita, e rivederlo su Steam mi ha reso entusiasta. È rimasterizzato in hd e si vede, io lo gioco con la grafica minimale ma già a questo stato è molto gradevole. È stato fatto un gran bel lavoro: le textures sono decisamente migliorate, ottima la luce e i colori. Ottimo come all'epoca il comparto audio, qui non è cambiato niente e va benissimo così. Ma c'è ancora del lavoro da fare: ci sono vari problemini di hitbox, nella scogliera capita di vedere i gechi appoggiati sulle rocce, ma appoggiati non sono visto che stanno a svariati centimetri di altezza. Capita anche con Ty, a volte è sospeso in aria e altre volte ha i piedi sotterrati. 
Ma sono piccolissime incertezze tecniche che si potrebbero correggere, il gioco è ben giocabile, mai crashato, pochi bug e nessun glitch grave. Se avete un gamepad della 360 per il pc dovete giocare con quello, mouse e tastiera non rendono al massimo la godibilità di questo gioco. Anzi, sarebbe da giocare comodamente spaparanzati sul divano.

Un grazie a voi sviluppatori per questo porting, grazie davvero, amo questo gioco. Aspetto il secondo capitolo che è davvero fantastico e il terzo che purtroppo non ho mai potuto provare.

25041837.review:
Most of us who purchased this have probably played the game years ago when it released on consoles, but this remaster is still a good buy for newcomers looking for a solid platformer, especially at $12. That's a good price. It's a complete game in Early Access. You can play from the beginning hub world all the way through to the final boss and bonuses. The game has many objects to collect and a solid variety of enemies to fight. The remaster is shaping up well. Although I encountered minor graphical glitches and some low frame-rates at certain points in the game, it was overall a smooth experience. I expect perfmormance to be improved as development progresses closer to release. I did not encounter any crashes or game-breaking bugs. The only inconvenience was having to reload a couple of levels to make a couple of collectibles spawn properly, but the menus and loading times were responsive and quick. Colors are vibrant, and it looks pretty good at 1080p. The soundtrack is solid. I found the dialogue and voice acting to be very charming and Australian. I played with an Xbox 360 wired gamepad. Controls felt natural and easy to use. My criticisms are few. The game can be too easy now that most of us returning fans are older, and the level designs / aesthetics are a bit repetitive. Still, I enjoyed my playthrough. Clearly worth $12. Looking forward to T2.

What did I play: Entire game. 100% game save with only two achievements left to unlock (I don't want to purposely die to run out of lives). 

And yes, nostalgia.

24853497.review: This game is a perfect example of what makes 3-D platformers good. All of the collectibles in game feel like they're worth your time to collect and give you a constant sense of progression. The only exceptions are the invisible picture frames, but they are not required to 100% the game, so it's fine. The worlds are quirky and interesting and the NPC characters can be charming and funny. The music is memorable and usually fits the worlds / bosses nicely. The story is very simple and easy to understand, and completing the game is very satisfying. This is also a rare example of a perfect PC port of an old game. Props to Krome for really making an effort to preserve this gem.

24836256.review:
This game is absolutely fantastic. The original was fun, well controlled, interesting and very nice. With a thousand recent remasters that have been incredibly iffy or downright awful (see Marvel Ultimate Alliance and MUV2), this was a definite risk. But alas, Kronos pulls it out. It's simply fantastic, and I'm incredibly pleased to see how they've done.
------------------
Graphics:  7/10

For PS2 age graphics, they've aged incredibly well. My resolution was nice and crisp at 1920x1080, and everything looked really nice. The textures were still pretty okay, but I'm solidly impressed that a game this age managed to be so nicely remastered.
------------------
Gameplay: 9/10

Everything's fast and fluid, and really nicely done. The mechanics have aged really well. Ty himself feels light, but solid, and definitely well done. Failed jumps and the likes never feel like you've been cheated by unfair mechanics, and even still, the whole ordeal is always good fun.
------------------
Story: 5/10

It's an interesting premise, with wildlife conservation themes sprinkled in through the whole thing. The characters and their interactions are all pretty unique and fun. Good stuff overall, but nothing new or groundbreaking.

============
OVERALL: 8/10
============

This game is a refreshing glimpse into the past, and a fantastic remaster in a time of absolute garbage. It's a blast to play this again, and I eagerly encourage anyone interested in old-school 3D action platformers to give this fantastic oldie a playthrough.

Or just go watch some porn for free. Either one.

24320355.review:
[EDIT] The game is out of early access! Congrats Krome!

THIS IS A GREAT GAME!
Heck freaking yea I reccomend this! Why you ask? Well let me tell you...

Positives:

+ A classic brought back from the dead! This game is (considered by me and others) a classic from the PS2 era! And you can tell this by the graphics. Even though they have been improving them. but it is still lots of fun, even to this day! :D

+ It's a solid platformer! Nice tight controlls, nothing to horribly hard, and good level design!

+ Quirky characters! From Shazza, to Maurie, to even Ty himself! They all have there own personality and, sometimes they are even funny!

+ Good sound/music! From the didgeridoo's, to hearing the wild animals, the sound is overall pretty good! And they are adding better sounds as it's updated! The music is nice and catchy and sounds very nice!

+ Lots of rangs! Boomerangs to be exact! From the simple Boomerang, to the Flamerang, to the legendary DOOMerang! And you will need these! You might need the Flamerang to melt some ice, or the Zoomerang to hit a button far off. Whatever the case, there are plenty of rangs to choose from!

+ One of the few good Early Access games! Krome Studios have done an AMAZING job with porting this game over from the PS2! They have been fixing LOTS of bugs, improving the camera controls, and improving the graphics and sounds!

+ They have improved this from the PS2 version! They have improved the graphics, camera controls, (they are going to be) improving the pre-rendered cutscenes, as well as adding Steam achivements, Steam Trading Cards, and leaderboards for the time trials!

Mixed:

= May feel familiar to those who have played Super Mario 64 or Crash Bandicoot. Ty shares a lot of similarities with other platformers. But this I consider a good thing because it does it well. But I can see how some would consider this bad.

= Is a collecta-thon. Again this in my eyes, is a good thing because it makes the worlds MUCH more enjoyable and explorable, but if you don't like that then you might not enjoy this game as much.

Negitive:

- Has bugs. These can be expected of Early Access Games. But fortunatly, as I mentioned earlier, Krome has been doing an AMAZING job at fixing and improving the game!

- Everytime you enter a level, it always wants to play the same cutscene with the same dialogue. This is just a minor annoyance as you can skip through it and it does not affect anything negativly but it is still annoying.

Conclusion!

This truly is a great game from the PS2 era! I'm so glad that Krome has ported/HD-ified it on over to the PC! If you like a good platformer, enjoy classic 3D platformers like Super Mario 64, or Crash Bandicoot, then you will enjoy this game!

9.5/10

(By the way, this is my first full review for a game on Steam so let me know how I could improve!) :D

24310199.review:
Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is a true gem from the past, which has not only been ported to steam for all to enjoy, work and effort is being put in to remaster the game as well to make it better than ever before, thus the reason for early access.

At its core, you have your standard platforming game with an amazing twist, you get to play with some ripper Australian action, staring a boomerang wielding thylacine (Tasmanian Tiger), how much more Australian can you get then that, well there is even a lovable dingo in this cast! 

You get a fun and quirky cast of characters who are for or against Ty's cause, and a simple yet entertaining story of our hero trying his hardest to save his family and friends from a deadly fate at the hands of the villainous Boss Cass.

Visually Ty the Tasmanian Tiger is great and getting better with the consistent updates, but it is also important to come in remembering that the original base game is 15 years old. 

Gameplay has a vast amount of variety, there is always something new you can do to solve any snags you may run into. Fans of collectable based games will feel right at home, since this game is based around collectable items to help progress story, and also unlock many extras, one such helping you increase your boomerang arsenal to take down the baddies. All in all, the game stays true to being a platformer at heart, and with plenty of lovely Australian scenery to take in. In one level you can be trudging through a dense rainforest, and then the next you could be riding through the wide open outback, or exploring a billabong.

Fans of platforming games such as Rayman, Mario, Sonic, Crash Bandicoot and other iconic characters will love to give this game a go. With the current modest price of 12 dollars, it is a steal given you have plenty of packed to the brim levels, an amazing cast of characters, and most of all a development team that is here to make a game that everyone can love. Not to mention the game has enough content that even kept me busy for over 9 hours of gameplay to get that 100%, and that is with years of experience and knowing exactly how to play from start to finish.

24235743.review:
[h1][b]Ty the Tasmanian Tiger[/b][/h1]
If you've played and enjoyed (how couldn't you?) Ty the Tasmanian Tiger in the past, [b]you should pick up this game now[/b]. You wouldn't be looking at reviews if you weren't considering it already.

That said, on to the review for those of you that still aren't so sure. Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was originally released on Gamecube, the original Xbox, and the PlayStation 2. I spent countless hours getting lost in this game as a kid and I was ecstatic to see that they decided to port it over to PC.

At the time of writing this review, the game in still in Early Access. Let me tell you for a fact, it feels far from it. This game is an excellent console to PC port. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is pretty accessible, but you have to pay attention to some of the NPCs' dialogue and cutscenes if you want to really follow along. It can be easy to miss. If you accidentally skip a cutscene, you can watch them from the main menu.

The NPCs in this game are amusing and somewhat inept. You might feel compelled to call child protective services on one of them as she keeps losing her children, but thankfully you're there just in time to step in and save the day.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Ty is a 3D platformer. You can do mostly what you'd expect with a game of this genre. You can jump, swim, glide, and climb your way through levels. The movement mechanics are tight, so any issues with falling off or missing a jump is probably your fault, as it should be. 

In every level there will be enemies for you to take down, items to collect, and friends to help. Thankfully, you will be growing an arsenal of boomerangs to help you accomplish these tasks with style. I really enjoy the variety of boomerangs to collect. Some are more utilitarian to help you find hidden items, and others can set your enemies on fire or slow down time. There's a 'rang out there for just about everyone.

Once the story is said and done, there's quite a few collectibles to find if you're up for it. They don't take a shocking amount of time to find, but if you don't look closely or consider alternative approaches to finding them then you may find yourself wandering a level for a couple of hours. Some of the levels are [i]big[/i].

For the competitive gamers out there, you can try to climb the leaderboards for each level! I personally haven't looked too far into these, but they appear to be working just fine.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
I don't currently have a USB gamepad, so my entire experience with this on PC has been with the keyboard and mouse we've come to know and love. Let me tell you, they feel [i]great[/i].

I have only had a few minor issues with the controls:
[olist]
    [*] Some menu UI elements cannot be clicked on, forcing you to use the keyboard rather than the mouse. (The developers actually have a disclaimer for this one and I trust they'll get around to it before the game leaves early access).
    [*] In the level "Beyond the Black Stump", [spoiler]aiming Ranger Ken's snowball launcher with W, A, S, D is pretty hard as it kind of jerks around by a certain distance. Rather than aiming for the frills I had to aim where I knew their path would take them and spam the fire button to take them down.[/spoiler]
    [*] When rapidly jumping up the small cliffs that form stairs for Ty on levels like "Snow Worries", the camera will jerk unpredictably and somehow bury itself beneath the terrain for a second or two, obstructing your vision entirely. 
    [*] You might have to dial the mouse sensitivity down, I know I sure did.
[/olist]

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The Developers have been hard at work remastering the game to make it feel more at home on modern systems. I played through the game at 2560x1440 (I saw lots of resolutions in the menu too) and its a definite improvement. They're continually releasing graphical improvements while keeping the game minimum-spec friendly.

The story-line cutscene videos are still low-res, but the developers are working on updating those as well. You can stillsee and understand what's going on in the cutscenes though.

The color palettes are bright and varied. I don't like to place much of an emphasis on a game's visuals because there are more important aspects to it. Keep in mind this is a game originally released in 2002. Don't expect Crysis and you'll be fine.

Based on the hardware reports, it looks like the game runs fine on Integrated Intel chips. If you're rocking a laptop without a discrete GPU, you should be good. 

I haven't noticed any graphical issues like artifacting or textures not loading.

I would comment on the audio but I don't think there's anything wrong with it and I can't muster much of an imaginary comparison from my past because I'm pretty sure the last time I played this game was over a decade ago (oh my god). It's also worth noting I'm a bit hearing impaired so I don't pick up on much of the audiophile stuff. The game sounds great to me, so that's all I've got.

[h1]Conclusion & other thoughts[/h1]
Like I said before, if you've played Ty in the past and you liked it, you owe it to yourself to pick this game up. It's more than a compulsory nostalgia purchase as the game continued to entertain me while I played through it and collected everything (I didn't 100% it when I played as a kid, 'cause I was stupid).

If you've never heard about Ty the Tasmanian Tiger before today, I hope this review alongside some of the others may have convinced you to try it. It's a great game, developed by people who really care about it (you'll frequently find the Developers in the discussions, responding to feedback, watching the Summer Games Done Quick speed-run).

I'm looking forward to seeing where the developers take this game. I know they have a few more improvements in the pipeline but the game feels like a finished product to me. They did a great job.

The more copies they sell, the more reasons they have to port Ty 2 and Ty 3. Let's make it happen, people!!!

Having owned this game when it first came out on PS2 I was very quick to buy this game once it came out now on steam, and i must say. It's a blast and better than it was when i first played it those many years ago.

I've completed the game to 100%. So and i didn't experience any crashes, missing items or anything. The only thing that i did notice with this game was that a few spots you lost a bit of framerate in. Otherwise, the game is great, controls have been perfectly ported and binded for PC, they've added neat features like being able to fight bosses again without having to restart the game and of course upped the graphics of the game.

It's hard to say wherther this game would fit someone right now with all games these days being much scavange survival, building and First person shooters. But for a nostalgic value or simply if you're someone who enjoys classic platformer games where you collect stuff. This game is gold.

I don't know if you should get it now though, since they do warn you that since they are keeping the game in early access to get feedback on functions that are broken and trying to optimize the game further, there is a chance that save files can be corrupted from updates that are made. And i don't think anyone would like spending hours on maps collecting everything only to have their save file lost and have to restart the game.

I played this game so much when i was a kid that i know practically everything by heart. So it didn't take me long to complete the whole game. But i'd say. If you've never played this game but want to experience classic old platformers in the style of Banjo and Kazooie then get this game the second it's out of early access. It's well worth it.

24195426.review:
Ty the Tasmanian Tiger was one of the first games I've ever played on my old gamecube as a kid. To see it being ported over to the PC is a great thing to see. It may not be as awesome as I remember it, with some levels later in the game that are huge but empty (Ex: Snow worries having a barren mountain to climb and Rex marks the spot has an empty ocean that really doesn't effect anything besides the time it takes to get from point A to point B) and that makes collecting everything a pain. The game still has some solid platforming. If you bought this game in the early 2000s, buy it here. The keyboard controls have been well intergrated so no gamepad is needed. 
The graphics (While dated in some parts) still hold up with the cartoony artstyle. And even with the over sized levels in the later stages, the levels are really fun to play and collect items to get new boomerangs. The game's greatest strengh is the Outback setting that's rare to see in games. This give the game an identity The only thing I 100% hate in this game is the characters. Ty is a cardboard cutout of a boy scout and picks one out of the same three lines when finishing a mission, Sly (Not the racoon) is the ultamate edgelord made from the mind of a 13 year old and comes off as annoying, and all the other characters as well as the bosses are completely forgetable.
Overall it is a good game. I'd say the only thing that's holding it back is the developers and being in early access. I feel like the developers won't add anything major to the game or provide any real overhalls that can benefit the game at the cost of nostalgia from the fans. Also I'm willing to bet that a lot of Ty fans won't buy this game because it says it's in early access. The game is finished, you can play it from start to finish just as it was in the Ps2, gamecube, and Xbox. It's in early access for patching the game and porting it.
I want you to buy this game, not only to get a good game but to also support the devs so that they can maybe port Ty 2 to PC. And I may be getting ahead of myself here but along with the release of Yooka-Laylee, this can encorage publishers to belive in 3D platformers again and more will appear on Steam.

23874235.review:
A competitor amonst the great platforming mascots, Ty rises once again.

The original was a great fun time of your usual collect-a-thon platforming and world exploring and still holds that today. This is no cheap PC port or cash grab though, no sir. This port, or small remaster if you will, is an example of what PC porting should be. Giving the game a small touch up in small places (such as the shadows being more sharp, some textures showing some polish, ect.) but still keeping what made it great in the first place.

As this is still early acess, there are a few hitches, but they're so far and few between you won't be complaining much. Overall, on my system, the game ran steadily at about 60FPS in most areas, baring the ocassional hint of lag in the more open levels. Again, very minor.

Gameplay is solid as ever, but I don't know about keyboard controls since I used an Xbox controller. There was a slight bug or issue with the camera at times where if I manually moved it with the right analog stick, it'd get stuck like that and not re-center itself. There's no button to re-center the camera either. Only way to correct it was to enter an area where the camera would fix itself back to follow behind Ty automatically. Small issue and didn't really cause any major problems as you could still move the camera around manually until it corrected itself, but it's worth noting.

Each area is unique, wonderfully detailed, and ripe with fun level design. All with memorable Australian-like music and colorful characters. Though if you're short of patience or don't like collecting random items, this may not be the expirence for you. You'll find yourself at many points in the game having to graze over the levels with a fine tooth comb looking for the last opal or cog, but finally finding them is a rewarding feeling, especially for OCD afflicted.

Overall a well made port of a classic platformer that's great for all ages. Hope to see the sequels on Steam soon so I can nab them up as well.

Everything you loved about the original game, minus a few things you hated, plus a few other enhancements.

In case you need filling in, [i]TY the Tasmanian Tiger[/i] was originally released on consoles in 2002. It's a 3D platformer featuring funny animals based on native Australian species who participate in an Australia-based culture, in which you run around in Australia-based environments, using weapons based on the traditionally Australian boomerang. (Are you picking up on the theme yet?)
The port is as fun as the original game was. To boot, there are some graphical enhancements and texture updates, and other things to make the game fully compatible with PC. [spoiler]And, unlike in the original, you get to use the Doomarang outside of the final boss![/spoiler]
Krome Studios (who are smaller now than they used to be) have been working tirelessly to overhaul the game to suit Steam. They also maintain good player-developer communication in the game's forums, so overall, they deserve the support.

If the developers make enough money off of TY 1 on Steam, they might be able to bring the rest of the TY trilogy to Steam. So play their game and tell your friends so they'll make lots of loot.

23471422.review:
TY the Tasmanian Tiger was one of my favorite PS2-era games of all time. It always surprised me how lukewarm the critics were towards it (most dismissed it as a soulless, but serviceable Mario or Banjo-Kazooie clone). Nothing could be farther from the truth than that.

Pros: 
+Unique, almost comforting atmosphere. This game is beautiful. No other way to say it. The levels/environments you explore are varied and detailed. ranging from the Outback desert, quiet rainforests, the Great Barrier Reef (probably my favorite), snowy mountains, etc. 
+Phenomenal soundtrack helps set the mood for each environment and is jam-packed with catchy, memorable, relaxing, intense, and even uplifting tunes (it's that good).
+Boss fights are intense, creative, and challenging.
+Gameplay can be addicting. Think of it as something like Donkey Kong 64, only much more streamlined and less tedious. It's an adventure platformer with collectathon elements. The large, beautiful environments really inspire you to go exploring.
+Great controls.
+Balanced difficulty. It's just challenging enough to avoid feeling like a cakewalk.

Cons:
-Some of the more hardcore players might find it too easy. 

Port quality: Really nice so far. The visuals benefit from a nice upgrade, with improved resolution, a maxed out draw distance (climb to the tallest point in the level Ship Rex and you'll see what I mean), a silky smooth framerate (locked 60 FPS), improved shadow effects, better use of color, and more to come. Very responsive controls too. The game feels vastly more playable and comfortable on PC than the original PS2  outing. The only cons so far are a few very minor frame drops (and stuttering) in some levels as well as brief graphical glitches here and there. Also, it would be really nice to see some more improvement on the textures as they look almost identical to the PS2 version (albeit with a higher resolution). Also, the cutscenes are locked at a somewhat choppy 30 FPS for some reason. Can't wait to see how the finised product will look and feel, seeing as the devs are constantly updating the game to fix any bugs or glitches (as well as improve the graphics further).

Overall: Worth a purchase. Probably the best 3D adventure platformer out on Steam at the moment and what looks to be a terrific port of an awesome game from days gone by.

23441747.review:
For those of you who played Ty in the past, consider buying this port and supporting these developers to add more content, fix more bugs, and port the Ty sequel games to PC in the future. They've so far showed devotion and hard work towards getting this game out of early access with the best quality they can manage. And there are some new extras that are a treat to old Ty fans.

For those of you who haven't, this game is basically one of the old classic platformer collectathons of the past, but with cool, unique features like the boomerang weapon, which is very satisfying to throw and glide with. Not to mention some collectibles are actually really hard to find at times, so there adds and extra layer of challenge for treasure hunting.

Speaking of difficult, I will admit this game wasn't too difficult so far, maybe that's just me having played this 12 years ago, or I've played many platformers. I'm more leaning towards the latter, so if you're crazy about platformer collectathons, expect Banjo Kazzoie levels of challenge from this game besides the ocassional speed-run challenge or wild turkey chase. But I will say the heart of this game is not for its difficulty but its diverse and somewhat open-ended levels. Just exploring the levels and finding all the things to collect while you glide, swim, look around corners and ditches and hige rooftops, it's quite fun. 

This PC port of the classic game has been optimized to work at the highest of framerates on the lowest graphic settings, trumping the PS2 in terms of performance. And the highest graphic settings add so much more detail and scenic beauty to the original, but is only recommended for high-end PC's.

Overall, a must buy for fans of Ty, and a good pick for those looking for a good platformer collectathon while you wait for Yooka Laylee. ;)

23046035.review:
This is going to be really long, as I have just got done beating the game 100% minus the picture frames.

Being the 18 year old guy I am, I grew up in the prime of video games. Jak and Daxter, Grand Theft Auto Vice City, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger, Seek & Destroy, etfc. I played many, many games in my time. But this game personally takes the cake as my all time favorite game from my childhood. Sure, it's outdated. Sure, there isn't much real plot and the gameplay isn't spectacular. But it's still an amazing game nontheless. The uniqueness of playing as a sole surviving Tasmanian Tiger throwing boomerangs in the great Down Under really stands out against games that all seem to involve one thing nowadays; guns and war. This game gives a feeling of actual meaning to your actions, if you watch and listen to the little plot there is. You are trying to save your family from the Dreamtime, where the evil Boss Cass imprisoned them. Every Thunder Egg you collect makes you feel one step closer to acquaring a talisman, which is what is absolutely necessary in the task of freeing your family. Collecting every item is not necessary to beat the game, but it does unlock a nice bonus that I will not spoil. If you're beaten the game 100% on the PS2, Gamecube, or XBOX. And for all the veteren players, there's a VERY special surprise for you after you have beaten the game 100%, too. Trust me, you will LOVE it. The Steam version comes with various new features, such as the ability to replay bosses, map your controls, camera-oriented throwing instead of in front of TY, leaderboard support for time attacks, and the special surprise I mentioned above. Since it is still in Alpha, many things can be added or removed. I personally hope there is some sort of player vs. player time attacks where you can race against each other in real time. Maybe even add in new bosses that can be taken on with two players. This game IS worth the money. I was going to buy a game I had wanted for MONTHS, but then I saw this game on Steam and I HAD to buy it. It is my childhood.

TL;DR - Awesome, fun, amazing source of nostalgia, happiness, childhood memories, new features, awesome secrets

The only cons I can think of are the ocasionally wonky camera angles, and the fact that it crashes often. You can play a full level 100% through, but it will likely crash on the next one.

All in all, I rate this remaster a solid 9.8/10. The only reason it is not a 10/10 is because of the crashes. I can't wait to see the end result of this masterpiece!

P.S. If you DO get it, go to Extras and check out the "HD Test", or something like that. Trust me, you will like it in one way or another.

22852788.review:
I played this game on the PS2, and it was one of my firsts, so I got this game as soon as I heard about it being on Steam. I absolutely love the Ty series, and can't wait for the next games to be ported.

Pros:
 - The game has aged decently well and poses a decent challenge.
 - Not too grindy if you want to 100% the game
 - Unique gameplay elements; boomerangs OP it seems
 - Krome is treating this game well and using early access properly; they listen and fix bugs

Cons:
 - Camera is unpredictable at times
 - Some of the 'rangs feel token and not too useful
 - That freaking turkey...

Neutral:
 - Low poly graphics reminiscent of the time
 - The dialogue can be silly at times
 - Early access bugs, but they get patched really quickly
 - Some bugs that were present in the PS2 version have been fixed

22851944.review:
It's the same game you played on the gamecube. Some new special effects, some new graphics, but overall the same game.

Pro:
-achievements out of the box
-VERY MUCH UPDATED special effects. Beautiful.
-controller support, with vibration (!!!!!!!!)
-can change look inversion for both up/down and left/right
-custom keyboard config support
-can skip text super fast if you have no time to read (or if you've played it already a million times)
-it runs
-somehow still early access, implying more content/updates
-subtitles
-some graphic settings, essentially the bread and butter of the most taxing settings are configurable
-despite the age, the sound is pretty crisp and clear
-price (12 bucks is pretty good)

cons:
-graphics, which somewhat updated, are still on-par with the original release
-no custom gamepad support (you can choose from 4 preset configurations)
-no super intensive graphics settings. You can change shadows, reflections, and draw distance to low, medium, or high.
-Some of the textures, like the shirts on the kangaroos, are kind of low still
-game seems complete, but still in early access for some reason

I understand it's a miracle we're even getting a pc release and I'm overjoyed for it. I can stop using my mostly reliable emulator and use the 100% reliable steam system for Ty now. To be honest, I had a hard time finding cons. Even the price is pretty good, which is somewhat rare when you look at remasters (cough cough SYSTEM SHOCK). The graphics are acceptable and the new effects are beautiful.

Fingers crossed for ty 2 and 3. I only ever played 1 and I'd be happy to play 2 and 3 legit somehow, without dealing with setting up my gamecube again.

First of all: DON'T LET THE EARLY ACCESS SCARE YOU AWAY! It seems Jim Sterling has made early access for this game seem a terrible thing, but the devs actually care about their game and update it regularly. Unlike some other devs, but that's not what I'm here to talk about.

22407852.review:
A remaster of a more obscure latter-day platforming mascot game, I recall renting TY during those weird Junior High days. So...does the game hold up?

Well...yes, actually. If you can get passe dthe game's "Australian Stereotypes: the game" You'll find a platformer that doesn't really reinvent the wheel but boy does it polish the mechanics of it's genre to a mirror shine. TY controls great, and somehow even makes water and swimming portions FUN! I know colour me shocked someone  figured it out.The level design is also pretty open, giving you a lot of options on how get around and collect all the things. The game is still fairly nice to look at even for remaster of game from the early 2000s that (As of this review) is still being worked on. From what I played TY is surpsingly smooth, well crafted platformer that Krome is clearly very proud of to try and remaster, and I'd say that pride is warranted.

The closest thing i can say to bad things is, again, the "Australian" theme is a bit of an aquired taste (though Krome is based out in Brisbane for what it's worth), the pre-rendered cutscenes look a bit murky on modern hardware (Something that for techicaly reasons can't really be helped but the in-engine stuff looks fine BTW) and for some reason the game's frame-rate is blisteringly fast which is a bit disconcretaing at first bug you get used to.

If you're nostaglic for this game, or like me really miss this style of game that has become rare in 2016 I'd recommend TY The Tasmanian Tiger. It does so many things right within it's genre I actually want to play the sequels now and hope they get remasters too.

22370496.review:
A game that was already great to look at and play gets modern updates and controls! If you loved TY the Tasmanian Tiger on PS2, Xbox or, like I did, on GameCube, then you will have a wonderfully nostalgic time flinging curved sticks at Frills and seaching every nook and crannie for items while collecting [i]even more[/i] items this time around in the form of achievements!

If you've never played TY before, but enjoy 3D platformers and are looking for some sweet collectathon action, look no further than this game to scratch that itch. There's tons of things to see and collect while exploring the beautiful Australian outback. Talk with endearing characters, fight humorous and challenging enemies, and experience a simple, fun story that sets up a great world to have even greater adventures in.

If you're playing with KBM, you will find the controls to be a great fit, utilizing a take on WASD for TY movement, rang switching and context actions, while the mouse controls the camera and offensive options. As of this review, Krome updated the swimming controls on KBM from the controller-tuned WASD for movement to a more natural mouse-based style. These new controls feel very nice and are a great step up from the older controls.

The game does have its rough and unpolished pieces as the HD process is gradually applied, but it is perfectly playable in its current form and I highly recommend this game to everyone, especially if you enjoyed and miss 3D platformers.

Pros:
-This game will run well on a toaster 
-Great game for people who like to 100% games

Cons

-short game that you could beat in less of a day

(Issues like frame rate, lag, etc...are getting fixed as we speak. The Krome team have been listening to the community's concerns and have been responding to them well, by updating the game to minimize any issues with the game)

This game isn't really too focused on it's story, but mainly focuses on the  aspect of collecting everything in the game in order for the player to progress. 

I would recommend this game to people, who are completionists, and have no problem spending some time to find all the collectibles. However, since the game is kinda short and doesn't have a story to fall back on, I would not recommend buying this game at full price.
